reviewText:
Apple to Apples is an extremely fun party game good for 4 or more people.

The set up is very easy.  The game comes with 756 red apple cards with name of a person, place, or thing on it.  There are 252 green apple cards which a characteristic of a person, place, or thing.

If you play with four people each person gets seven red apple cards.  You then draw a green apple card that the judge reads to the players and lays face down on the table.  The other players have to choose a red apple card that best matches the green apple card.  The judge picks the red apple card that is the best fit and the player that laid down that red apple card wins the green apple card.  If you are playing with four people the first person to win eight green apple cards wins the game.  (That number is reduced when there are more players).

It's even more fun because everybody gets to be a judge.  The role of judge passes to the next player going counterclockwise.

There are many reasons this game is very fun.

First, you can get some very funny comparisons.  For example, let's say the green apple card is "dainty" - delicate, elegant, graceful.  Let's say you have several red apple cards but the only one you can come up with is "hippopotamus."  The judge may find that such a funny opposite he or she may choose that card as the winner.

Second, you can't cheat.  The judge is the sole person who decides who wins the green apple card.  You can hide and not let the judge know what you played, or you can sit and lobby the judge to choose your card.  It's a wide open contest.  It does get a little annoying when someone always chooses their spouses card regardless, but it's not against the rules.  You can even play to the personality of the judge.

Third, you can play with a lot of players and the more players you have, the more fun the game becomes because you get even more funny comparisons.
And finally, the game is very fast moving and often after one game is over, people want to play it again.

I highly recommend this game for an easy, fast paced party game.

Her shape resembles the old ponies (not like the tall, skinny-legged new versions of some recent acquisitions of hers); more like the ones of my childhood.  But this one is too big to fit with the nearly ubiquitous standard smallish figures and too small to fit with the elegant new ones.  It's annoying.

That said, she's very beautiful, and her hair is long, silky smooth, and awesome.  The stickers were a big hit with my daughter.  The lights, while not a huge deal, add an element of glitz.  My daughter is very pleased with her.

All my grandsons from age 6 to age 10 loved the Mixels we purchased for them for a gift when we recently visited. They loved the creativity of being able to make several "mixels" from one or adding one or more mixels together to make bigger Maxels.  Great idea for cute little figures.

The idea behind the doll is is that you can change her from a mermaid who has a teal tail to a mermaid princess who wears a pink dress simply by pressing her necklace. To change her back, pull the dress back up and snap it into the back of her waist. It works fine, but I wonder how long this can hold up with lots of play. My 2 1/2 year old daughter is fascinated with mermaids and she loves Barbie dolls, so this is naturally a great toy for her. She has played with it non-stop since she's received it and I ended up buying the DVD of the same name to go with the doll. Based on her initial joyful reaction and the fact that she carries her around everywhere, I would rate this doll 5 stars. However, from an adult/ consumer perspective this Barbie doesn't feel as well made as other dolls. She's a little flimsy and lacking in quality and I would probably only rate her 2 stars. Therefore, I averaged her rating to 3.5 stars. The fact is she's a very pretty doll with a unique feature and she makes my little girl happy.

reviewText: Review of "Even Steven's Odd!- The Game of Wicked Fast Dice Rolling."  I received this game from the Vine Program in exchange for an honest review.  I played this game with my youngest children.  They loved it!  You select a "dice challenge" card with a dice combination on it and roll the dice as many times building in the dice holder until you get it right.  Speed is key!  If you win you gain possession of the "Steven" doll and the challenge card. After ten rounds the player with the most cards wins the game.  Great for kids learning addition, etc. and to keep their minds engaged.  Definitely a contender for family game night.  Comparable to Yahtzee, etc.  Five stars.
summary: Simple, Fast, and Very Fun Game!

reviewText:
I have an almost three year old nephew.  I love him to death but he is a messy little thing.  Like he can look at a room and he messes it up.  :) I shudder to think what he could do with paints or markers.  However, he loves to draw.

I have a tween daughter who loved these toys when she was little.  When she was little it was before tablets were everywhere and I always took her magnet doodle pad with us when we went out to eat or somewhere where I needed to keep her quiet.

I ordered this for my nephew, who like I said going on 3.  When it arrived, my tween daughter, immediately opened it and started playing.  I had to convince her to give it to her cousin.

One of the things I like best is that the color is "rainbow" when you write on it.  I've never seen that before on one of these toys.  It's cool looking!  It comes with two magnets  that work well.  It seems well made and he loves it.

The company does send a random color, but honestly who cares?  My nephew can play with pink or red or blue, it doesn't matter!

My only complaint is that the drawing board appears smaller then the picture.  That certainly doesn't affect the fun my nephew has had with this toy and if he has no complaints, I am a happy Auntie : )

I did receive this product for free in exchange for a review.
such a fun project to do with a toddler.  My son loved painting this and comes with lots of stickers

reviewText:
I received the letters and am very pleased with them.  My three-year-old grandson is an early reader.  Lately he has been expressing the desire to spell, but lacks the motor skills needed to write.  I had a few mismatched hand-me-down letters, but he needed a complete set.  I wanted something with both upper and lower case so he could learn capitalization when he is ready.  I chose this set of letters because it had enough letters including duplicates of the popular letters so he could spell most words.  He was here last night and his new letters were the only toy he played with the entire evening.  They were a HUGE success!  I would definitely recommend them.

I'm back to update this review.  We've had the letters for a while and they are still a favorite toy.  He now spells words and plays with his letters by the hour.  During a recent sale I purchased another set to give to his daycare provider.  Now he can play with them at daycare as well as here.  Surely one of the best purchases I've made for him.

reviewText: We bought this for the upcoming christmas for my daughter who is five, we put it together today and tested it out. All sensors function properly and it definatly sounds like a real horse. The assembly was a little tricky, however the instructions were nice and clear. The one problem I am having is once you zip the zipper and click it into place, getting it undone has become a problem (still currently working on it). So if you are buying, just make sure everything is nice and tight (you'll understand why when you read the instructions) before you zip the head to the body. It requires 6D batteries and I must say the on off switch is epecially nice and easy to get to as is the battery case. Overall I think it is worth the money, I know my daughter is going to love it. This is also predicted to be a hot toy of the season so if you can buy it the sooner the better. Happy Holidays.

reviewText:
It is hard to go wrong with talking animals!

The objective of the game is to collect materials and clues from a castle to identify which of the servants stole the magic ring.

It is a collective game.  The players work together to solve the mystery; everyone wins, or everyone loses.

Every turn players have the choice to: search a room, talk to an animal, or feed an animal.  You have to find the food that the animal wants before you can feed it, and generally, when you feed the animal, it gives you useful information in exchange.  Some of the rooms allow you to interact with items such as an anvil, a magic well, etc.

Here is the Dr. Games evaluation:

GO/NO GO criterion

* Complexity: Whoowasit scores well on this one!  The game plays at three levels of complexity.  It defaults to the Easy setting.  The Easy setting definitely is appropriate for the 7-10 year old crowd, and the Hard setting was difficult even for a set of 30 somethings that I played it with!  You have a limited number of choices each turn, and the game actually helps you keep track of what you have done and gives verbal hints on the lower complexity settings.

* Balanced: The game is emminently balanced, because it is a cooperative game.  All the players win or lose together.  If the players work together and have a general plan then they will win.  If the players do not cooperate or make random moves then they will lose.  It could not be more balanced.

* Chance: The game has the appropriate level of chance for its theme.  The game is randomized each time you play, but there is not a lot of chance during the play.  Once the puzzle and the clues are set, they are set.  Revisiting a room and doing the same action nets you the same result each time.

* Clarity: The game does fine in this area, but if I had one constructive criticism then it would be that not everything was obvious in the rules.  For example, my groups were not sure when you needed keys just to open the trunks or whether you needed the keys to open the doors too.  In some cases, e.g., the Tower, the game would not allow you in until you had done something else.

* Reasonable Time: Once you know the rules, you can play a game from start to finish with four players in less than 30 minutes.  Yes, it was concluded in a very reasonable time.

BONUS criterion

* Social: Because it is a cooperative game, there is plenty of opportunity for positive interactions with the other players.

* Unique/interesting Mechanic: The magic box with talking animals is a very cool and novel approach to the mystery game genre.  Bravo!

* Inform: The game does teach you about logic, how to deduce and how to search in a structured way.

* Rewards Throughout: little victories within the game is a better approach than all or nothing at the end, and Whoowasit delivers both big nd little rewards throughout the game.

As a bonus, I could imagine a youngster playing the game by his or herself.  While you can play with up to four, with slight modifications, you could play this game solo.

I highly recommend adding this game to your family bookshelf.

In service,

Rich
[...]

I also bought the matching dessert plates.  12 plates for less than $5 is an incredible value especially for an American Girl merchandise.  I wanted to order the birthday set (for the dolls) from AG website and it cost $40 ! Needless to say, I passed on that set.  I purchased pink plastic tablecloth and fluorescent plastic utensils from the local Dollar Store for the "perfect" AG tea setting ! reviewText:
We have a ton of Barbie and Disney Princess dolls in the house, but these are made a little more like Bratz dolls than our other princesses (not that I'm calling Ben a princess, though he is very pretty).  The articulation, scale, and accessories are just much more Bratz-inspired, which I find curious.  On the up side to that, Mal's dress is decent: a woven base with an embroidered lame.  With a cool two-tone hairdo that my 9yo desperately wants, it's a pretty cool set.  Ben, on the other hand, has a less-inspiring screen-printed suit and a crown that won't stay on his hair.

While my girls liked the set quite a bit, I felt like for the price Mal is a solid 5-star, Ben is 3, and the set lands in the middle at 4 stars.

This one was kind of an impulse buy (I had a discount and needed to use it immediately). However, as an adult, Mars fits my personality. She might be bossy but she also seems the most mature.

Sailor Mars is honestly the best Funko Pop I own. The colors, the pose and the hair are all correct. I have quite a few Gaming and Hero related Pops, yet this is the only Animation Pop I own. It doesn't really fit my style, and yet it's still the most vibrant and well-crafted Funko vinyl on my shelf. The stand is packaged separately in the box, which I wasn't expecting. I'm used to it being packaged in the plastic with the figure.

EDIT: Time has passed and Mars is having trouble standing. She's leaning back too much. Originally this was a 5 star pop but I'm knocking it down one.

Seriously, this is the most fun I've ever had from a board game.  Introduced to us by Wil Wheaton's tabletop, we had to try it.  Basic premise is a cooperative game of cure the diseases.  Why does the red disease always end up being referred Toby players as bird flu?

W tried the game with my 6 year old, and even she had fun, though less able to grasp the strategy part of the game.  The only bad thing is the luck of the draw when it comes to picking the characters, we've found that as long as you have a medic and researcher, you stand a good chance of winning... But not guaranteed, because the game is actively (through odds and random chance induced by shuffling) trying to kill you.

Starting the game by having the player most recently sick is also a nice touch.  Pick this up for your next party, non hard core D&D types (myself and my wife played many many years ago) really enjoy this game, as much as hardcore tabletop gamers. And novice casual board gamers will enjoy as well since it doesn't have the d&d table top feel.  Really fun game!
summary: The game is trying to kill you!

reviewText:
Its a great system, but I have 2 basic problems with it, one much more important here than the other.  The less important issue is that its a small system.  This is less important because I knew about that and I knew the system is expandable.  So, the more important issue: when the item arrived, it was in damaged condition.  I knew I wasn't giving it to my son for a while (I bought it for his birthday), so I opened the box to check how bad it was.  None of the wooden pieces were connected (as they should have been) to the cardboard.  One of the marbles in the bag was actually cracked in 2!.  In general, I opened the box to find a mess.  But I cleaned up that mess, attaching the wooden pieces to the cardboard (the ties were there), tossed the broken (and yes, sharp!) marble, and generally made it look good.  Today, we actually gave it to our son.  We went to set up one of the configurations and I discovered one of the wooden pieces is actually broken (with an inch wide piece of 1 or 2 layers of the wood broken off).  This is really unfortunate.  It seems like a great product, but either we were shipped a box that had a set someone else messed up OR the shipping of the product--either to us or somewhere else in the supply chain--was really bad.  Still, it works well and my son seems to love it (I don't think he realizes there is a broken piece).

Added: I no longer think the set was used.  I now just think the wood pieces are poorly constructed.  It may be that the wood used is bad, that the glue holding the wood layers together is bad, or some combination, but whatever it is the wooden "tracks" break off.  This is a real shame.  We thought we were buying a product that would be far better than the plastic marble racer sets--I even foolishly thought it would be something my son would be able to pass on to his children (when he is older I will give him my old erector set!).  And I thought we would be adding pieces to it, little by little, so that he would build cooler and cooler systems.  Alas, while this looks like that sort of product, its not.  Wooden toys always look good, but if you use crap material, you get a crap product, whether its plastic or wood.  Its still fun and educational, but I can't recommend it.  In a nutshell, you might as well buy a plastic set if its cheaper.  This won't last longer and you won't want to add pieces.
summary: Great toy, but received w/broken pieces! Keeps breaking..

reviewText: This was a Christmas present for our 7 yr old and she loved it! Kept her busy for a while and she has played with it for quite a while since. Usually, she is quick to destroy the original design and create her own structures. This is one of the few she left as is.

I-Sobot is a fragile toy robot. It has many warnings about the many ways you can break it.

It is quite an entertaining little bot when YOU are controlling it. But if you put down the remote control and watch, I-Sobot just sits there, yawns a bit and then "falls asleep." For EVERY action that you want it to perform, YOU need to hit buttons or joy sticks on its remote. There are hundreds of key combinations, none of which are easy to remember. (I think there was one called A.A.A that did something fun.)

It is missing some of the key features that most robots have these days. It has no mode that will let it run on its own. It cannot sense the edge of a table and of course will break if it falls. It cannot sense something in front of it. It only has sensors that keep it from falling over, although with feet nearly as long as it's legs are tall, It does not need sensors that much. It has a small vocabulary of words it understands and it does pretty well with that if in a quiet room. It's own voice is not very loud which is a good thing as it is quite chatty. There is a program mode which is a bother to use.

If you are looking for a robot toy with a bit more "robotics" in it, the Robosapian and other Wowee robot toys are a much better bet. If you want to teach your older child (12+) about real robotics the Vex kit is the way to go.

If you are looking for something to ENTERTAIN a 8-13 year old that is VERY careful with toys or an adult that needs another bit of technology on his desk, this would be just the thing.

PS. You've got to love that first "review." It was probably written by the I-Sobot marketing team.)

[...]

I got this Ventress as part of Clone Wars 2009 Exclusive Collectible Tin. This figure has: - ball-jointed head - ball-hinged shoulders, knees and ankles, - swivel forearms, waist and hips, but - no articulation on the elbows. The sculpt and paint of this figure is spot-on Ventress from the CG animated series. Hasbro got this figure right. To top it off, this figure includes a fabric skirt that is removable. The only thing that could be seen as a minus is the lack of actual articulation on the elbows. However, it would have been very difficult to put ball-hinged on such tiny elbows and still make it look good. I think they did the right call. This figure also includes two red lightsabers and an hologram of Count Dooku. Overall, this figure that offers great likeness and good articulation.

reviewText:
My nephew helped me review this Iron Man 3 figure. I gave him the toy and watched his use. The figure is a nice large size with moveable body parts and a built-in missile launcher. Upon opening the action figure my nephew played with it for hours. In fact, he carried it with him wherever he went for several days.

I have mixed emotions about the shooting missiles. One, the launcher works great. My nephew had no trouble loading and launching missiles. They projected across the table or room (several feet). On the other hand, as with any small pieces these missiles can be easily lost and could be swallowed by small children (toy is not recommended for 3 and under).

The figure also has a range of messages that will play when you push a button. The messages and lighted eyes require 3 AAA batteries.

As far as generating fun and excitement and lots of active play, this action figure delivers.

I bought this for my 3 1/2 year old daughter for Christmas and she loves it! In the package, you get Teresa dressed in a removable helmet, painted on riding pants, a floral shirt and denim vest (removable), and cowgirl boots, the horse with movable legs, and a small plastic brush for the horse. No assembly is required, though you will need 4 AAA batteries that are NOT included. The battery compartment is located under the horse's stomach. Teresa measures about 12" tall and the horse measures about 11" x 11 1/2" and was larger than I expected. The details on the horse are beautiful, including the painted on purple saddle, the blue eyes, and the etched detailing on the horse's mane.

To operate the horse, hold Teresa horizontally over the horse and insert the pink piece in her hand into the ribbon hole on the side of the horse until you hear a click, then rotate Teresa towards you and down to stand up and you'll hear another click of the ribbon. At first I was nervous about bending the ribbon outward, but it seems well made and functions properly. Once Teresa is in position, you can press either the button on the horse's forehead and he'll start to walk, she jumps on, and rides! Or you can press the button on the side mane once she's in standing position and she will jump on first, then the horse walks as she rides.

My daughter takes horseback riding lessons and she gets so excited over this doll because she rides just like her. Everything seems well made - she's knocked it over on the kitchen floor several times and it still works perfectly fine. The only negative about Teresa is that due to the nature of how her legs have to split to jump on the horse, you can't really use her as a regular Barbie because she can't sit down or stand up straight (one leg is longer than the other). As far as the horse is concerned, the mechanics of it do make a loud noise when in operation and it doesn't work on carpeted floors because the legs get stuck on the carpet fibers as it walks and ends up tipping over. It will operate on tables, hard wood, and tiled floors.

Overall this is a super fun toy that any horse loving girl would enjoy! It's really cool to watch her jump on by herself and has given my daughter lots of hours of enjoyment!
summary: Super Fun Toy Any Horseloving Girl Will Enjoy!

I contacted Hitec and they said I could pay to ship it to them and they'd look at it, but that hardly seems worth it. A charger isn't something I'd expect to need replacing, especially when you're buying a name brand and paying good money for it. While it did work for a while, the fact that it has failed already, and in so doing could have easily caused a big fire, I'd stay away from this charger, you can do better, and you can do it for less money.

Normally you would have to mask everything yourself to get that kind of paint separation, but this kit is molded in those colors right off the sprue. This also means painting the kit yourself is easy, and you won't have to overlap multiple colors on one piece. The posability and shelf presence the Sazabi has are eye catching, and if you do take the time to paint (or at least panel line) and decal this model, it will have a really commanding presence. I can't praise this model enough, Bandai did a phenomenal job recreating a gorgeous MS into a display worthy model kit

There's a lot of play packed into this playset! At 15" x 12", it does not take up a whole lot of space. The ship has a detachable scout vehicle that attaches to the nose. The ship opens and makes play space. There is a cannon that shoots missiles. There's a claw and a jail area for captured prisoners. You can place two figures on the side, then using the little levers, have them battle it out! The set includes 2 figures, 4 missiles, the claw, turret (cannon), and the scout vehicle.

The set looks and feels to be well made. It's made of a thicker plastic. The set will work with other Playskool Heroes Star War sets. The figures fit well into the play set and are easy enough to manipulate that the 3 year old is able to play with it on her own. Even though my son is 9, he has enjoyed playing with it, too.

It works, after a bit of work.  It seems that my Turnigy 9x, my Mac and FPV-Freerider are a bit sensitive to this whole operation and it took me a week to find the trick, thanks to reddit user flayzeraynx.  No driver installs or anything, here's what I had to do:
"Connect to the USB on the any Mac device. No need to install any driver. Remove your module from the back. Plug the stereo audio cable to the simulator cable slot (its at the back, below the module).. do not turn the Transmitter, the TX will get the enough power from the audio cable. Now create and select a new model, select acro plane, and mode 2, reverse the elevator channel. Now open freerider on the MAC and select usb controller from the input and select"

Then I also have to calibrate the controller every time I start the app, it's a little annoying, but FPV-freerider is free for one map and cheap to buy the rest.  If I bump the USB or the trainer port when I'm in the app, I lose it and have to close the program and start from the beginning.  Hope this helps someone else!
summary: Tricky with my Turnigy9x and my Mac, but it works!

Many friends had recommended Ticket to Ride for our family, and they were right!  We love it!  I wasn't sure if my boys - ages 6 and 8 - would be able to manage it, but they are figuring it out and having a great time.  We started by playing with our cards open on the table and coaching everyone together, so we all learned how to play at the same time.  Now that the boys have sorted out how it plays, they are able to go on their own, and have even developed their own strategies.  It fits great with two Thomas loving boys.

Play moves along quite smoothly, with each player trying to build train lines that connect up specific city to city routes as designated by destination tickets.  Routes are claimed by collecting series of colour train car cards that allow the player to place their plastic train cars onto the board.  The only point that we found a bit confusing is that there are five colours of train cars - each player gets a colour, but there are also coloured routes that while they match player colours actually have nothing to do with these colours.  A bit confusing at first, but after a few rounds you quickly forget and it all makes sense.

If you want to get a feel for how it plays, I recommend the mobile App version of the game.  We purchased it shortly after the board game, and every member of the family loves it, and uses it to hone their game when on the go.  We took the board game to the grandparent's house last weekend, and we had 2 kids, 1 parent and 2 grandparents all playing together, with the kids showing the grandparents how to play.  Playing with 5 players added a new level of strategy to it for sure!

A fun game for all, but a bit addictive .. beware!  We also have the expansion on our Christmas wish lists.
summary: A great game for the whole family

Barbie Collector 2011 is my introduction to the Barbie Collector series; to be honest, I'd never heard of it and chose this little lady to amuse my surrogate niece when she comes to visit. To tell you the truth, we both appreciate her.

I'm surprised that the current crop of Barbies is this nice because the mainstream Barbies I've seen over the years don't impress me (and whatever happened to Midge?). This Holiday 2011 Barbie suggests the Barbie I knew (and, frankly, didn't appreciate at the time) from childhood--dressed to the nines in apparel only she can carry with hair and make-up just so. In other words, Barbie 2011 is eye candy to the extreme. Beautiful gown, beautiful pose, altogether just lovely.

I realize that that these are collector's items and aren't really meant for children but I do think Collector Barbies would be a nice entree into the world of collecting for a not-too-young and somewhat responsible little girl--dolls of this kind would look beautiful on designated shelves and would be something to look forward to annually (and certainly less expensive than an add-a-pearl necklace albeit not as valuable). Regardless of whether she's intended for an adult or juvenile collector, Barbie Collector 2011 Holiday Doll will enhance pretty much anyone's decor (not to mention satisfy a collector's hunger). And interestingly enough, she's dressed perfectly for St. Patrick's Day. :)

I bought this board game for my 6 year old niece as a birthday present.  She wanted me to play it with her and two of her cousins (6 and 8 year old boys) the night she received it.  The kids had a blast and we eventually had to make them stop playing so their parents could take them home.
The basic premise is that you draw from a deck of cards and the kids must go find something inside the house that matches the description on the card. What can I say? I am an oddball. I love rubber duckies. The more unusual, the better. My current favorite rubber duckie is the Yin Yang Devil Duckie. The picture of it is pretty self-explainatory. The black and white emblem on the chest of the rubber duckie is the yin yang symbol. Yin Yang comes from Chinese philosophy. Two seemingly opposite natural forces are entwined together. One can't exist or function without the other. In the case of this adorable rubber duckie, the two forces that are intertwined is good and evil according to the description. It is obvious that there is no educational use for this cute little critter but as a rubber duckie collector, he is a must have. He is too cute. If you love the devil duckie line like I do, Yin Yang Devil Duckie is a must have.

This is a nice starter set if your toddler has moved on past the larger blocks, and it is also great just to add to your collection. Personally, I love the fact that the storage tub is a taller, slimmer size. It makes storing it away in a corner of the room even easier. It takes up less space overall. The lid just lays on top, in place, and does not snap or lock, but that's ok with me. Less chance of little pinched fingers and it's easier for a child to open and close themselves.  There's no specific handles on it either, but there is a nice "lip" sort of handle on each side. It's plenty adequate enough for carrying or lifting it.

Thus set comes with decals to put on some of the blocks, as well as a vehicle base with 4 wheels, a little boy figurine and a cute little dog. The boy and the dog both attach to the blocks. There's also cards to show you how to build a few items, like alligator and dinosaur, robot, etc.

Overall it's a nice set whether you're just starting out or adding to your blocks. The tub for storage is an obvious bonus and the neat size and shape of the tub is appealing as well.

The ONLY downfall to these blocks is... no more rounded corners like the larger blocks have and having to control your potty mouth when you step on one unexpectedly. Ouchie!!! One of the worst feelings in the world lol!
summary: Very nice set with great slim storage tub

reviewText:
My two-year old is in the upper age limit for this toy, but he really loves it. The toy has three settings:  first stage, second stage, and third. The first stage, as you would expect, is more simple. So when you press the carrot, the toy says "orange." In the second stage, the ideas get a little more complicated. So if you press the strawberry, and it says "Strawberries are my favorite fruit." In the third stage, you start getting longer phrases and songs, even jokes. For example, when you press the broccoli, it says, "Hey broccoli. How's it growin'? Haha." My son likes all three stages, honestly, so he ends up getting a lot of variety. He especially likes the songs, and I kind of wish the toy offered more in that area--though I'm still really happy with the content and sound quality of what is available.

The one meh thing about the toy is the watering can. I notice my son doesn't play with it much. The crazy thing is that it does actually sound like water when you turn it upside down. It just isn't that fun, unfortunately.

As far as what parts come off and how the toy works, the watering can is separate, but it can hook onto the side of the yellow caddy. The three fruits/veggies (strawberry, carrot, and broccoli) can come out of the caddy completely. When you push them into the caddy, they will talk to you. The flowers don't come out, but you can push them and they will talk to you, too. Also, my toy DID NOT come with batteries (even though the product description says they are included), so make sure you have two AAs handy, just in case.

Overall, though, this is a fun toy. Fisher Price says it's best for kids 9 mos to 3 years, but I think 3 years is pushing it. In my opinion, this toy is ideal for 1- to 2-year olds.
summary: Fun, interactive toy for one- to two-year olds. Excellent sound quality.

I bought this about a year ago for my son who was almost a year and a half. I have to say that this is such a cute toy! The bottom of each egg is a different shape and fits into its matching spot in the carton. The way the carton is designed makes it very easy though for little ones to put the eggs in. Even if the eggs are not put in their correct place you can still shut the carton. The egg shells are very easy to take off and put back on as well. The only drawback is that the carton itself is very hard to open. My son is now 2 and a half and still has alot of trouble prying it open. This is one of the few toys that he has continually played with for over a year now. Its such a unique toy and I am very happy to have it as part of our collection!

The first time we played Indigo was with another couple in their 30's.  It took about 30 minutes to read and comprhend the rules, and complete our first game.  The gist is that you are given tiles on a large grid and you create little pathways with the tiles you randomly draw.  The tiles then lead reward pieces back to the 'home base' that you share with another player (though you are on opposing teams).  When a reward jewel is able to travel a complete path to your base, both base owners earn a point.  That's it.

That said, there is a fair level of strategy, especially after a dozen pieces or so have been played.  The path can wind from one area to another in moments.  The rules are simple, the pieces are sturdy and beautifully decorated and the playtime is fast and fun.  My only knocks are that the rules could be a little more complete; to offer solutions to possible problem scenarios, but they are not half-baked.  We only ran into one odd play choice and we were able to come to a group decision on how to handle the outcome.  I would have liked to see higher scoring possibilites, maybe additional scoring gems or multipliers or something.  One of the pieces is worth 3 points, while all of the others were worth 1 or 2 points.  In every single game we played, whoever won the 3-point piece ended up as the overall winner.

I would easily recommend Indigo to casual and 'hardcore' gamers a like, and for ages 6 and up.  Easy to understand, but compelling enough to play a few rounds before moving on.

This set ALMOST gets it right. I was at first skeptical of camouflage outfits but once I opened the box I was impressed. The camo looks COOL. And I think the shape of the Episode III helmets gives the clone less of a cartoony and more of a serious presentation (I actually have come to like the Ep 2 helmet when viewed alone, but the Ep 3 helmet is superior when they are compared). I also like the swamp hovercraft that is the mini-build of this set. It includes a couple of the stud basters which, in spite of their large size, are awesome because they work very, very well.

The downside of this set to me is the strange shape of the Scout Helmet. Instead of altering the Biker Scout Helmet from ROTJ, the visor section is wider and has a blue color. I have nothing against the color but the shape makes me think that all the Scouts are bug-eyed or have exceedingly large foreheads. My gripe boils down to the decision not to alter the same, old clone head to include a blue or black headband (like all the Batman mini-fig heads have a white headband to give Batman white eyes), a blue or black head covering (like the Tie pilots), or just black hair. These options would have prevented the shape of the head from being compromised.

In spite of this the two clones with the Ep 3 helmets went on a tropical vacation with us (too bad for them...so did the Rancor).

My 2 yo LOVES this play food and so do I! Some reviewers complain that it's too small and not life size, but it's supposed to be small.  It's for small hands! And it's perfect for my tiny girl. It's a nice flexible plastic so less likely to crack than some of the harder plastic toys we've had.

Some reviewers also complained of funny smells. This must have been fixed because we did not have this problem.

Also at least one reviewer complained (with pictures) that the Mac and cheese and cereal were poorly glued together. This was also not a problem for us. (See pics).

My only two complaints are with the bread and muffin. This is supposed to be a healthy collection of food so I wish the bread was whole wheat. Also the muffin comes apart too easily. My daughter complains often that the "lid fell off." Not a deal breaker by any means. I will probably just glue it together.

Overall, I really like the Tonka Ricochet. My six-year-old son and I had a lot of fun driving it around the neighborhood, doing off-road, jumping makeshift ramps, scaring the neighborhood cats, etc. It's a simple control vehicle -- not the finest controls in the world, but it's all responsive and works -- and it has a good range. The battery pack, once its fully charged, seems to last a decent length of time, too. The booklet said a full charge should last about 15 minutes, but that must be 15 minutes of continuous wheel turning; we clocked in a good 30 minutes of normal driving one time, and it still had some juice left.

My complaints about this are mainly technical. Specifically, the battery back, which is removable only by unscrewing a plate and then trying to unplug a very tight plug connector. It's unnecessarily difficult, especially for a child, to have to do this after each use (which is more or less how often you'll want to charge it, after each full play session). I've had other RC cars that charge right in the vehicle -- you just plug into the side. Why didn't Tonka go this route?
summary: Fun, but some poor design choices

Bought this after being impressed with videos on tactilebrain.com, so kids and I can sharpen our math skills too! I am very pleased with this soroban. Not too small in size and has 17 digits with the "ones" markings starting on the 3rd rod from the right, so first 2 can be used for decimal numbers. Perfect! I like the single color of beads as they are less distracting than colorful ones out there, though others may not agree. As described, it is plastic and lightweight which I like (portable) -- but because of this, other beads move easily when moving a bead or if frame is shaken. This might be a dealbreaker for most, BUT I knew this beforehand and knew to place soroban on cloth like a fabric placemat or kitchen towel while being used. Problem solved. I was thinking of getting one with a "reset" button, but after watching videos above, I saw how much easier it is to reset it by hand -- plus I won't have to deal with the possibility of malfunction of reset mechanism. (To reset - tilt soroban towards you so all beads slide down, then lie soroban flat on surface and slide thumb and forefinger along the beam from right to left so "heaven" beads move up.) To top it all, I got this product at a great discount from snagshout in exchange for this honest review. Hope to get some more. This is an ancient but amazing tool that everyone should go back to!

Update 9/8/15: Kids and adult have no problem using this using pointers above, however the relatively small beads may prove a challenge to younger kids or those with "chunky" fingers. We bought a chunkier for little one so far but will advance to this as soon as able to. Definitely buying at least one more of these though, one for me too!  Some helpful websites:

Kojima ebook 1954 soroban
http://www.egitimcininadresi.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/12/Soroban-kitabi-ingilizce-takashi-kojima.pdf

Soroban handbook
http://webhome.idirect.com/~totton/soroban/THE%20ABACUS%20HANDBOOK.pdf

Math worksheets (for practice)
http://www.nurtureminds.com/worksheets/math.php

This is one of the Leapster Games that is actually pretty age appropriate....I find some of them are far too difficult (Star Wars) or easy (Tangled) for the stated age range.

My almost-five can play this on his own, and he's prowled through most of it and enjoys it, but it's not "done".  Some things he'll come back to, which means it's a bit tough on the math portions but I like that...if it were too easy my money would have been wasted.  About the math, while he does need help with some, I've noticed that the repetition is a really cool thing since these are basic math facts that need to be memorized.  He doesn't complain either.

Another thing is that it's very user-friendly for him...Scooby Doo needed lots of input from me as he couldn't seem to understand the prompts or what each task was asking for.

One thing that annoys me is that LE cuts back on costs by going to a cardboard package (good for the earth) but never thinks of lowering the price.  It would be nice if there was a way to store it better now that they've went to plastic.
Also, on this game the volume seems off...it's as if there's no level 1 so you have to distance yourself if you want to keep your sanity while they play!
summary: Super happy kid...not too hard, not too easy

A very good game for all levels and ages on the Platinum tablet.  It is simple enough for very young children and has enough variety - and characters from a favorite show- to engage the school age kids.  My grandchildren are 4 and 6, both are very advanced scholars and read well above grade level, so I had some concerns that this might be to "baby" for them. It isn't. They have watched Paw Patrol and know the dogs from the show.  To play this game, instead of having a cartridge or smart card to insert in the tablet,  you have to take a picture of one of the playing card in the deck that comes in a metal box.  Each card has a different dog and when you choose him he goes on a "mission" with varied activities.  There was a free demo game available but this one, with the cards is much better and both kids played it for hours.  They have both had the Leap Pad tablets since they were toddlers and had really outgrown their LP2s.  I have written a separate review for the tablet itself.
summary: Great game with popular characters from the TV show. Good start to the Leap Pad Platinum line.

The 36" T-Rex Skeleton is an amazing model to have in your collection.

It's large, easy to put together, stands well, and looks absolutely amazing.

The model is easy to assemble, and equally easy to take apart for transportation if you ever need to do so.  It stands on it's own very well, and looks great on the included stand.  The 36" size is impressive, but it's not as gigantic as some other 36" size models because there's not a lot of "bulk."  What I mean is that it's a lean, mean, 36" long...not some big, bulky, giant thing.

The thing I like most about the kit is that it gives you a good base to start customizing with paint for other looks and effects.  For instance, I've used quite a bit of black acrylic paint to both bring out details AND to essentially "degloss" the plastic pieces.  I feel that after adding the paint the skeleton is much more realistic looking, and it also looks more finished.  This is something that even a beginning hobbyist could accomplish, as the acrylic paint is easy to clean off if you end up doing something that you don't really want to do.

Overall, I'm really happy having this model in my collection.  I plan on getting a plaque made for it and adding it to my "Jurassic Park" display in my movie room!!!

We own the "Cover your Assets" game by Grandpa Beck and love it, but we heard that the Skull King game was even better.

We got it, and it's quickly become a favorite. The rules took some getting used to because we'd never played a "trick" game like this before. There's a couple youtube videos that explain how it works, but it comes down to each player guessing how many hands they are going to win each round. If a player wins the exact amount they guess, they are awarded points. If not, they lose points.

What makes this so fun is chanting "Yo, Ho, Ho!" at the beginning of each round, hitting fists against the table with each word. The last hit, the players open their fists, revealing with fingers out how many "ticks" they think they can win that round. It's lots of fun and adds the Pirate-ness of the game.

It does take a little getting used to, but play a couple practice rounds after watching the youtube demos and you'll get it.

Instead of including bigger blocks, they just inserted more of the single peg blocks. Now I wish I would have purchased 2 of the 80 count package instead.

Overall, I love the Mega Blocks. I just wish they wouldn't have put so many of the single peg pieces in the 200 count.

March 2012 Update - My son is nearly 4 and still plays with the Mega Blocks often. If you don't mind having a toy with several pieces, this is a terrific buy for a 1 year old that they'll be able to use for a couple of years.

reviewText: EXCELENTE

I may change the # stars based upon response from company question regarding 'Connection Lost' issues vs battery life.  I paid for the unit as a gift for my son, who is not into cars but really loves this set so far.  He's configured different tracks and has easily adapted to learning how to use it.  I find a couple of things puzzling, such as the ratio of car size to track, the need to have on a complete flat surface, and times where the AI just quits for a split second causing the car to drive erratically.  The biggest issue, as noted above, is a 'Connection lost' issue after about 1 hour of run time.  I replace the car's AAA batteries and issue is eradicated, but intervals are too short.  I used the removed batteries in other products which seem to work fine.  The company states rechargeable work great but I can't see how these can retain power any longer than alkaline, which means the connection will definitely cease in even shorter intervals.  Not sure why other users haven't complained here (although I saw a couple in their forums).  Overall, I think it's a nice concept but am concerned the 'addictive' reviewers here haven't waited long enough to let that wear.  Adding more cars and track in unique configurations may help sustain interest, we will see.

Awesome! It cost $2 to fill at local party store. It was smaller than I thought but actually ended up perfect sized. My two year old boy seriously loves this thing. We refilled it again after about a week and he still loves it even when it's emaciated and in need of a refill. Very well designed and balanced. Love how the legs are perfect. This doesn't float above the child's head. It floats just perfectly so the feet touch the ground. Everyone thought it was a hoot and I'm tempted to get more "pets" and a helium tank. Would make a fantastic party favor for kids. Should be used with supervision because of the ribbon "leash". My son did rip off two of the legs but we just taped them back on. This is a winner and very affordable for how much fun it's provided! Get one or more, you won't regret it. Love this!
summary: Fun till the cows come home...and a long time after that.

This is a big shark, and it takes a lot of helium to fill it up. Not all balloon shops will fill a balloon this big.

Then you need to transport it home without letting it fly away. Then you need to make sure the 11-year-old doesn't let it go in the living room with the cathedral ceiling. Then you need to drive back to town to buy a "grabber" from the hardware store. Then you need to find a fifteen foot stick to ducktape the grabber to. Then you need to attach some kite string to the grabber's handle. Then you need to bring in the ten foot ladder, and while two people hold the ladder, you need to climb up and grab the ribbon that is dangling from the bottom of the shark. When the grabber loses its grip on the ribbon and bounces to the corner of the cathedral ceiling, you need to go upstairs with the stick/grabber and grab the ribbon from the balcony. Easy peasy. Do watch the youtube video about attaching all the pieces to the inflated shark. It is very helpful. It is a lot of fun. We bought two - one for spare parts.

BTW: Did you know that helium is a non-renewable resource? It is rare on earth and we may run out by 2018. That's why helium is so expensive.

This ball is for ages 3 and up and if younger has to be supervised. My daughter will be 2 years old next month and she cannot quite sit on the ball without help. That still does not stop her from trying, she loves to do things on her own. I definitely supervise her while using this ball. It comes deflated so you will have to pump it up which is easy and quick. They provide you a foot pump with hose as well as an english manual. This manual also has different ways you can use this ball which is awesome. It is very well made and durable. The handle is nice and sturdy for your little one to grasp onto. The top of the ball is nice and smooth and the bottom half has some texture to create some traction. Even though my toddler cannot reach the floor with her feet quite yet she still loves to play with it. She is able to bounce it around like a bouncy ball, you can get a good bounce out of it even though the handle gets in the way sometimes. She also practices her kicks with this ball or roll on it. Love the versatility of it and interesting ways to use it listed in the manual. Great product that will grow with your kid. My daughter loved the logo in the front, we got the pink ball and she was immediately drawn to the logo and the bright colors. This is definitely a fun hopper ball for her. *Complimentary sample was provided to me during a promotional offer in exchange for inspection & honest unbiased evaluation.
summary: Fun and can grow with my toddler ages 3 to 6

Most kids today are familiar with stop-motion - they've seen it on Youtube and TV. Shaun the Sheep and other popular kids shows. This little set introduced them to stop motion basics.  The figures are held together with elastic cord, and each "joint" has different fixed angles. Rotate one way and it's 90 degrees. Another and it's 45 degrees. The hands and feet are nice quality suction cups that STICK.

The camera phone tripod is basic, but works.  Same for the free app.  Even if the kids get bored of the stop-motion animation activity, the little robots are fun to play with. For some reason they remind me of "Terrance and Phillip" from South Park. The positioning is pretty coarse, but we're not talking $500 models here!

Overall it's fun, and for $10 you really can't go wrong.
summary: Fun making stop-motion, OK app, nice basic figures.

reviewText: Great

As someone who works in the toy industry, I see a lot of dolls and action figures that are beautifully created and/or imaginative, but still don't personally want them. The Monster High line is the exception. The pieces are so visually appealing, wonderfully designed and executed for a mass-market toy, that I can't resist collecting just a few for my own enjoyment. When I saw the new large size, at such an affordable price --practically the same as the smaller versions!-- I didn't even work hard to justify the "where the heck will I put it" factor, and just ordered the Draculaura.

And she is pretty great. The same grace as the small ones is there, same delicate hands and cute face, same fun fashion, and a nice new elbow and knee articulation style. But to achieve such a low price point, it seems they chose to make some sacrifices that might annoy a collector, though maybe not a child. There are rough spots on the feet and some edges that catch on the clothing, and relief-printed tiny numbers on the arms. The knee and elbow joints are just SLIGHTLY a different pink than the rest of the skin. The whole body is very light and hollow-feeling, and I wonder if it will break easily. The bangs, as others have mentioned, are shellacked and unbrushable. Also, the attention paid to the smaller dolls' clothing didn't translate up to the larger. With more canvas to play with, there is so much opportunity for fine detail that was just ignored, even the velcro fastening is unneccesarily thick and heavy. (Though all the seams are very tidy and the necklace is quite nice.) The shoes on the large Draculaura are especially clunky and made of a thick stiff rubber. Nothing like the shoes of the smaller dolls, with all their crazy sculpted details!

I'm hoping that this size does well enough in retail to warrant improvements in the next wave. Maybe they were just in a rush to get these out before Christmas? The one thing that bothers me and probably won't ever be fixed, is the torso sculpt that they've chosen-- it gives the doll an intensely swayed back. Yes, all the little ones have it too, but for some reason, it's exaggerated in this size, so much that she looks hunchbacked if she's standing without totally sticking out her little belly.

But all those things are rather minor irritations to me, and I still am very happy with my purchase, and tickled pink to see her sitting languidly on my shelf. I think this size could be a real break-through in fashion dolls; most of the larger non-baby dolls are the American Girl type (with the great outfits/accessories/stories, but the boring/ugly faces). There could be some really beautiful clothing and accessories made for these larger ladies, if Mattel will just give them a bit more of a fighting chance...

As with all the Fashionista dolls, I love their diversity. She is so cute with her curly red Afro! I love her watch and boots, and I love that she can cross her ankles like me. I have a floral dress that looks like her top, so I had to get her. Yes, I identify with all the Fashionista dolls in some way lol. They're all snapshots in fashion history.

I wanted to get my son some board games for Christmas, and I thought regular Monopoly would be too complex for him at this stage. So we got Monopoly Jr., and it's definitely easier for kids...perhaps *too* easy for some kids that are 7 or older.

The Monopoly Jr. board is rectangular, with less spaces than the adult version. Set in an amusement park, there are also Rail Roads, but they're just Roll Again spaces. The "properties" are amusement rides, arcades, or attractions which cost between $1-$4 for a ticket booth. When you land on a space, you MUST buy a ticket booth. Players have an opportunity to "kick out" other players if the property is split, but not if there's a 'monopoly'. There are some Chance cards, but they function in the same way: direct the player to a particular square where he may buy a ticket booth.

As with regular Monopoly, if you land on a space occupied by another player, you have to pay the player the fee. Otherwise, you must BUY the ticket booth.

There are four colored plastic game tokens: a yellow carousel horse, a green "log jammer", a blue bumper car, and a red roller coaster car.

There could be more variety to this game without making it too hard, so in my opinion, the game is a bit too simplistic. However, it's a nice way for the parents to spend time with the younger kids. My son seems to like playing the game, although he hasn't asked, specifically, to play it until Christmas.

Quarriors was first and it is a phenomenal game (if you like dice games).  So why did the same company put out dice masters?  isn't it the same thing?  Not quite.  They are similar, but there are a few differences to take into consideration before you decide.

FIRST-- Dice Masters is a 2 player only game, where Quarriors hosts up to 4 players per game.  Depending on your game group, one of these might be easier to get to the table than the other.  If there are 4 people, usually they will want to all play a game together...plus, if you don't have other 2 player games available you don't want to make people sit out and watch.  If you have a larger group, though, this can be a great filler for 2 people to play while they wait for others to show up or to finish another game.  TRUE- Quarriors can play with only 2 people...and it IS still fun that way... it just doesn't shine with only 2.

SECOND-- The theme.  This may, or may not, have an influence on your fun.  You can answer that question yourself.  Dice Masters is dripping with the Marvel theme (well, this version.  there are also others coming) while Quarriors has its own theme of magic users summoning creatures.  This is aesthetics, but could make a difference on your playgroup.

THIRD-- The style of play.  There are some differences between the two (Dice Masters allows for a Yahtzee style of re-rolling every time...while Quarriors only allows a re-roll if a certain dice side allows for it to happen.  Although it sounds odd...in play form I prefer the Quarriors mechanic for re-rolls).  There are other differences including (but not limited to) the ability to have cards that other people can not use (Dice Masters) and multiple  options of how/where/when to play dice (Quarriors with Expansions) and even what the objective is (Dice Masters=kill opponent...Quarriors=gain victory points).  BUT THE REAL DIFFERENCE IN PLAY is that Quarriors feels like a "boardgame" where people are all sitting around playing a game and that is it....and Dice Masters feels like a "tournament" style game where you are forming your "deck" and going head to head with an opponent.  Both of them are good styles of play...it just depends on which one you are looking for from this game.

LASTLY-- The cost involved.  Quarriors base game is more expensive, BUT it is ready to play right out of the box...and it will give you MANY hours and games of fun.  Dice Masters is cheaper and CAN be played right out of the box...but it is an extremely watered down version of the game that you won't want to play more than once or twice before knowing that you NEED more cards and dice.  Quarriors expansions tell you what you are getting (if you want more card variety, get Quarmageddon.  If you want new ways to score points get Quartifacts. etc..) so you can choose what you want, pay for it, and play it....slightly expensive, but you are getting the complete set for that expansion AND getting hours and hours of new game out of it.  Dice Masters is a "collectible" game...which means in order to get new characters you must buy random packs (2 cards and 2 dice per pack) in order to expand your playability and HOPE that you aren't getting cards you already have or dice you don't need.  At about $1 per pack at your local game store, the packs are cheap and it can be fun to have the excitement of opening something up and seeing what you have received....but it will likely take you A LOT of money to get enough characters and dice to have a selection that will provide you with enough variety for hours of play.

IN THE END-- Quarriors and Dice Masters are both great games.  Decide which one makes sense for you and your group based on player count, theme, and style of play.  Then make sure you are willing to spend the money for it-- Quarriors=higher base game cost...but more hours of play from the base game....Dice Masters= expensive to get to the level of Quarriors, but still having fun getting it there counts for something too.

Good Luck, and Choose Wisely!  :)

We own the older version of this toy, which we bought to encourage our son to say animal names. This toy improves on that model by being larger -- it's taller and has an added gate, which you can use to house the animals.

But I liked the older verion better for the following reasons:
- sounds.  The older version incorported animal songs; this one more just has toys
- off/on switch is on the bottom, which makes it harder to access.
- fewer animals.  The older version also included a pig.
- male farmer.  The older version had a female farmer which felt more unexpected and kinda cooler.

This version is fine if you don't know any better, but I think Fisher Price should be adding animals to this set, not taking them away.

Between Tow Cities is a great light and strategic board game. The title is indicative of the game play, in which you are not only trying to win for yourself, but must also balance helping the person on either side of you. The game is incredibly social due to it's co-op parts and the entire game you are trying to maintain this balance of both your cities while simultaneously trying to screw over your partner such that they have worse options for the city between them and their other neighbor (the game play revolves around taking two tiles from your hand and then passing the remaining to the next person - 'commonly referred to as a drafting'). Component wise, the wooden pieces are great, and the tiles are made of super thick cardboard. The artwork is very clean and looks great. All in all, I can see this game being pulled out for any occasion and enjoyed by novices and heavy gamers alike.

The Athena is a great high altitude performer with a classy look. Does it matter exactly how high it goes if it goes so high you can't see it? I just lost one today when launching with a C engine since the wind thermals carried it much further than I anticipated. If you launch this with a C engine and want a chance to recover it, cut a significantly sized hole in the center of the parachute. You can start with a smaller hole on a less powerful A or B engine so as to make sure it slows down the rocket just enough to prevent damage. The great thing is that this is inexpensive and pre-made so if you do loose the rocket it's not hard to get another. All I had to do with this rocket was tie on the parachute and cut a hole in the parachute so that it does not drift too far.

reviewText:
My son and I both like this game. Unlike with the other reviewer, our pump works just fine. We've never run out of burgers before the belly inflates and the jacket bursts open.

However, I suspect the problem they ran into is that your 3yo (in our case) has to stand over the toy, hold hands in CPR form, and push down on the head (while you hold the feet) and push until it clicks once for each number. A #3 burger means three CPR pushes and three clicks. It really is hard to push than it should be.

Like the other reviewer said, the belt never stays closed, and the jacket usually bursts open one notch right at the first pump. The losing pump is still pretty obvious, though, with the jacket bursting open completely and both arms flying up in the air.

We both find it enjoyable and easy to play, but don't expect this to be a table game; it's a floor game due to the inflating position required.

One great plus: all the burgers and the die store right inside the pig. After the last round, just feed the outstanding pieces to him (don't inflate) and it's ready to store. I like games that are unlikely to lose pieces :)
summary: Fun game, and good for CPR practice

When LeapFrog sent us the Number Lovin' Oven for review, I couldn't wait to see what my five year-old and his younger cousins would think. This toy is so much fun!  The kids adore the chunky pieces of food and accessories.  The oven sings tunes that are catchy and upbeat (and not annoying!) and the volume has three settings if you don't want it cranked up to full speed!  The lyrics teach so much more than counting.  I find it so helpful that this little oven reinforces things like washing hands and sharing (the sort of things that preschoolers often needs reminders of).  Just the other day, my son tried to help out in the kitchen without washing first and all I had to say was "what does the oven sing?"  It's also helpful when I'm cooking, because the little ones can cook along with me!  Best of all - ALL 16 parts fit inside the oven for easy storage. Thanks LeapFrog for that one! This is a great gift and an awesome addition to the LeapFrog toy collection.

Many compare this game to Risk, and while it does have that placing troops element, that's really where the comparison ends. In this game you continually redeploy and conquer (no dice battles) until your numbers run short. Then you put your race in decline and pick a new one. Sounds simple, but the twist is that each race has a built in power and an additional special power that's randomly paired with it at the game's start. Additionally you can choose from the "next" race or pay to get one deeper down the line. With all the races and abilities this game is different every time so tons of replay. While the characters and themes could have really been anything, the ones they chose are really fun and well illustrated. Days of Wonder does a fantastic job with artwork and presentation on all their games. I also like that they give you different boards depending on the amount of players you have, instead of just saying "dont use those spaces." It's just a lot nicer to be on the board you're "supposed" to be on. Small World is a simple game to learn and you'll be playing your first game within 20 minutes of starting the instructions, but it's also a LOT of fun with very little randomness and a lot of strategy. This is one we keep coming back to. Definitely a must-buy.
summary: Strategy game that's loads of fun

reviewText:
We love this toy. I had an older version when I was a kid and my older children did also. This one is a little different from those because it takes batteries and makes noises. Personally, I prefer the ones that don't make noise just because my daughter's developmental therapist told me that noise toys rob kids of pretending which is an important part of play. As such, I will probably just leave the batteries out.

What I really like is the updated look of the people and animals. They are realistic with real arms and/or legs. This is an improvement over the old ones because they are basically shapeless with a head.

Another nice improvement to this over the old farm is that the silo attaches and it closes. This allows you to put the pieces inside and keep everything together whereas the old one was two piecs that did not attach or fold.

Definitely a great toy for helping kids develop pretend play skills.

Time from first open to play:  5 minutes, Rating 4.5

Audience: It is a bit gentler, i.e. not as crude as Cards Against Humanity (CAH).  Cards and answers can be as nasty as your group, which means you can play with your close, close friends, but you can also play an inter-generational game with your 18+ kids and the grandparents (as long as they aren't TOO conservative").

Gameplay:  Great flow, lots of fun.  Basic idea is that there is a rotating reader, who reads a card.  The cards are something like: "Things that are good about dating an older man." or "Things that are kinky" or "Things that make a woman scream YES!" or "Things a proctologist might nickname his finger".  Each person writes a response on the included paper strips.  The reader will read them all aloud, and then each person guesses, trying to match one of the responses with the person who wrote it.  If you are matched, the person guessing gets a point, and you are out.  If you are the last one standing who hasn't been guessed, you get two points.  Rinse and repeat, with the reader position rotating to the next person.  btw, we tried playing with 3 at first - definitely more fun with a greater number of players.

I will offer a small gameplay variation - every time someone guesses your response, instead of a point, you take a shot.  If you're playing with the grandparents, just make sure it is a small shot!

Nice that there are 8 sharpened pencils in the box so you don't have to worry about finding writing supplies!  I like also the fact that with these cards, you can play them again unlike some other games where once you make it through the set of cards, you're done - this game can be different every time, even if you run across the same cards.

The one thing I didn't really care for is the instructions, where they are obviously trying a bit too hard to be irreverent and funny.  But that doesn't impact game play at all.  For example, they say "We really don't wanna hear your comments about this game, but we know you're gonna bitch about something, so go ahead..." - you get the idea.  There are also some minor gameplay issues when playing with larger groups - it is very difficult to remember who is out and who is still in, so using a marker or card isn't a bad idea.

I was given a copy of this game to review, opinions and experiences are my own.
summary: If you liked Cards Against Humanity, you'll like this one...

Bloxels was a totally new concept to us, but I thought it would be a useful and fun activity for my eight-year-old daughter who needs to work on her focus and concentration. What comes in the box is pretty straightforward - a large black game board, lots of colored blocks (apparently 320), and a fairly detailed instruction booklet.  What brings this all to life, of course, is the Bloxels app, which we were able to download on both an iPhone and an iPad.  The app itself takes a little exploration to fully grasp, even for an adult, and it would probably be best for an adult and child to work together on the first couple of projects to get the hang of Bloxels.

My daughter did get a little frustrated because we had to do a specific block pattern initially in order to unlock the app features, but once we got through that, everything is pretty much at your fingertips.  You can follow the booklet instructions and create game scenes and unique characters.  And using the app you can register and join the Bloxels community and see a wide variety of user-created projects.  For game scenes, it all comes down to understanding what the different colors represent, such as blue equals water, white equals story, and green equals ground.  The booklet has all of this information, but I really had to help my daughter out to get her started on this.  Beyond that, there's the camera issue.  Game board information (blocks and colors) get transferred to the app via the iPhone or iPad camera.  This takes a lot of patience, and I can easily see where this might frustrate some kiddos.  Light glare is often misread as white (story) blocks, and if you move the camera slightly before the app fully gets the game board configuration, you can end up with some very odd results.  But you can read the board with the camera as many times as necessary to get it right.  When we finally created a character, it took about five tries to get it to appear correctly on the app (and even then, a couple of colors were off).  But we really had a blast making subtle adjustments to allow the character to walk and jump, and it really looked great on screen when we finally got it inside the game.  My daughter was extremely proud of her accomplishments, and that's what this was all about -- the payoff from concentration and hard work.

All in all, I would recommend Bloxels as an engaging activity that offers fun and creativity yet demands patience and concentration.  Like any truly great game or activity, the more effort you put into it, the better your results will be.  Children can surely benefit from projects like this, and I know that my daughter and I will continue to use Bloxels as a fun and educational activity.
summary: Fun and creativity meets concentration and patience

reviewText:
We purchased this game over a month ago and love it. We own the adult version of Apples to Apples and have had numerous game nights filled with fun. If you have played the adult version, you know that the people referenced or words used, can be puzzling for children that are younger. For that matter young adults as well. The kids always wanted to play it with us, but I felt it was too complicated. This is a great solution. The vocabulary and people referenced are within reach for the kids. We do have a few younger kids that don't completely understand the references, but they love playing just the same. I think that it is best suited for 8 and older. The average game takes around 25- 30 minutes. The directions are clear and the clean up is easy. Sometimes I shy away from games that have a million pieces, or are not playable if a card or piece goes missing. If you loose one or two cards you still can play the game, which is important in our household. The kids have even played this game with friends and had a great time.
  We have played the game as a family and had many laughs and an entertaining time. I highly recommend this game for your family collection.
summary: Fun family nights, or even a great 30 minute distraction while you get chores done around the house

reviewText:
Or by magic...I mean magetic. Either way...they are fun. My daughter loves them. They are big, to they aren't a choking hazzard. The magnets are securely locked into the back of each letter.

So far after 2 months of daily use we've only had 1 magnet fall out of a letter, and that was after the letter was thrown against the refrigerator in a fun game I like to call "Let's see if we can make them stick from a distance!" (My 1 year old is pretty good at it, but I'm still the reigning champion. The round letters are the easiest to make stick when tossed. So I usually cheat and give the kid the square letters. It's ruthless, but she's got to learn the ways of the world eventually.)

All in all, it's a good toy. I saw the smaller, more common letters in stores but they were tiny by comparison and practically spelled out "We are going to end up under things and down the air conditioner vents!"

UPDATE AFTER 4 YEARS

These are now being enjoyed by my second child. They have lasted VERY well over a 4 year span. I have been very impressed with these. Despite regular use by kids over multiple years, they still look new. No broken letters, no lost magnets.
summary: They stick to things! It's like they were molded in a sourcerer's cauldron of magic!

reviewText: my daughter was over the moon for this

The premise of this set is that SpongeBob and Squidward are bad neighbors. Fans of the show know that Squidward is an ill-tempered and unlikeable lout, while SpongeBob and Patrick are bumbling, naive, and cheerful compadres. The story here is that Spongebob is testing his new jellyfish launcher and accidentally blows up Squidward's wall while he's taking a shower, paving the way for comic mischief. In terms of build-quality and materials, this is a superb building set. Like all of Mega Bloks' sets, the pieces are well made and instructions finely detailed as full color drawings. Mega Bloks definitely does not skimp on the printing, and for this set, it comes with two instructions books. One person can build SpongeBob's pineapple while another can do Squidward's Moai. The sets are shown at an angle for maximum clarity and plenty of markings on the illustrations are shown to guide you along step by step. The tops of adjacent pieces are even color coded to make things easier to see. The level of detail is on par or better than Lego sets I've built in the past. If you lose them, Mega Bloks has the instructions on their site as PDF. 498 is a whole lot of pieces, so younger children may need adult assistance. Mega Bloks seems to love making things launch in the SpongeBob line. Mega Bloks SpongeBob Krusty Krab Attack also has a patty flipper and other shootable parts. The jellyfish launcher here is somewhat suspect. Since there are no springs or any mechanism to shoot the dart out, it doesn't really fly. You have to push hard on the back to eject them through the hole, but this is not what I would call a launcher.

reviewText: Well over all the truck does as it is advertised to do. It rumbles along, backs up, headlights turn on and flash all the while making construction type sounds and if you press down on the driver figurine loud music plays. I'm a big fan of the Toystate Caterpillar Construction Flash Light And Night Light: Bull Dozer as they are very durable and well made. But this truck, not so much. It is lightweight so that it can be carried by little people, but it almost feels flimsy and I am really disappointed that the tires are not solid wheels. In fact they are half a wheel and hollow. While this might be mildly diverting for indoor play I'm thinking it will get trashed pretty quickly outdoors. In fact I'm pretty sure the batteries are going to outlast the lifespan of the truck. I really miss when good, solid metal Tonka toy were made. This isn't even close.

I really like this little toy. You get 20 hard plastic cards with different pictures on them. This toy is bilingual and each picture has the English and the Spanish word for each object. Objects can be animals, food and more. You also get a bucket with a handle so you can carry all your cards around and there is a slot in the top of the bucket where your baby can place them and exercise his/her fine motor skills.

The cards are hard plastic, but the picture are stickers, so this may not hold up well if your child tends to put everything in his/her mouth and chews on it. It's too bad because this could have been a great little bathtub toy as well if not for the stickers. Regardless, it's a cute little learning toy that your baby will love. I haven't met a baby yet who doesn't like a good bucket to carry around and put things in. The price is right on for this toy. Not too expensive, but a great toy.
summary: Cute bilingual learning toy for toddlers.

I do love dolls like this and will put her aside for my own personal collection. Of course shes fit for a little princess, but also a very nice collectible. Very high quality and quite well-designed. Simply keep in mind that if this is for a young princess, there are a few picnic parts that can be easily lost or misplaced. FEATURES: Have a magical tea party picnic with Princess Sofia and Clover the Rabbit! Princess Sofia wears a precious pink party dress with a matching teatime hat Bring Clover and four interactive tea party accessories close to Sofia to hear more than 40 fun phrases! Adorable Clover has a bobbling head, long furry ears and wears a delightful blue bow tie Includes a dessert tray and picnic basket, tea pot, two tea cups, two cupcakes and a pink-and-white picnic blanket PRINCESS SOPHIA: Disney Sofia The First Talking Sofia and Animal Friends Disney Sofia The First Royal Family Giftset Sofia the First Sofias Transforming Dress Princess Sofia Surprise Slides Board Game Sofia the First Talking Magical Amulet Sofia the First Royal Shoes Princess Sofia Surprise Slides Board Game Disney Sofia The First Princess Sofia Doll Disney Sofia The First and Minimus
