reviewText:
I really like this game.  It is unlike any other game I have ever played.  It requires more interaction and collective strategy than most other cooperative games.  It has six different scenarios which are really very different games, so it has a lot of replayability.  Because of the high level of interaction required to win, this game will be enjoyed most by people who know each other well and have good teamwork skills.  An overbearing player could really make this one a drag.

The rulebook is not very well written, which can make the game a challenge to learn.  I recommend the Castways Quick Start Guide to Robinson Crusoe, which is available from the Z-Man Games website.  Once you learn the rules, the game goes smoothly.  Plan on having three hours or so of free time.  This game is great for a cold winter day.

The game is hard to win, but alternative rules can make it easier.  Add Friday or a companion dog to your party of castaways and you will have an easier time the first few times you play.  I also like the fact that there are male and female versions of each of the main characters.  This is a minor thing, but male bias in game characters really annoys the heck out of my wife.

Perhaps the biggest challenge with this game is finding it.  There is a lot of interest in this game but not a lot of copies.  If you are interested, grab it while you can!
summary: A Very Challenging Game that Requires Great Teamwork

reviewText: One word, "AWESOME!"

I got Cuponk! from a friend and the second my oldest son (12) saw it in the car he opened it. It didn't look like anything he had seen so he was dying to try it out. We were actually on our way to grandma's and when we arrived he began to play with it immediately. He got his 7 y/o sister into the game too. They had so much fun that I was able to visit with my mom without one interruption! I saw my son with it on his head and his sister watching intensely to see if he could make it. They laughed over and over as they tried to bounce the ball off different objects in grandma's house. The ball is so lightweight I wasn't even worried about them breaking anything. When it was time to go they put everything in the container and off we went. At home with all his friends and brother (10) it was the same thing.....kids cracking up as they tried all kinds of combinations. It's cool because they can use the cards for ideas or just do their own thing. My middle son is very into science so he tries to make a perfect set up. The oldest is wild and just goes for it. They love to challenge each other for some healthy brotherly competition. They even involve their sister and use her toys to bounce off. My oldest son said to me....I love this thing, it makes you want to keep trying new things! The Cuponk encourages them be active, use their imagination, create new "courses" and be competitive. All around its been a hit at our house!
summary: Great for a group and to play alone!

When this bed came out my son was just about to hit 2 and we were in the market for a toddler bed.
Few reasons we liked it off the bat.

1.) It's adjustable.  He could start with his crib mattress, and when he outgrows that we can change him to a twin size.  This should make this bed last for years while he grows up.  Who knows maybe 9-10 and this will still be functional.

2.) How much cooler can it be?  He loves the lights in the front.  We read his books to him in front of the car each night before he goes to bed.

3.)  It's super durable since it's the hard Step2 plastic throughout.

It's a bed first and foremost, so it does what it's intended to do. I am sure any kid would love it, and of course dad does too.
It really looks cool in the middle of his room.  I expect it to last a long time, and may even have resale value when the time comes for him to move onto a real bed.

The only bad part about this was the packaging of the stickers that need to go on.  They were just thrown in the box in a bag, and had gotten all wrinkled and unusable.  A quick call however to Step2 customer support and they sent out a new batch right away.  Small inconvenience but the company took care of me.

Price is higher then the little tikes beds, but this is much bigger and definitely looks MUCH nicer. Would recommend to anyone who has a son who is into Cars.  We paired the bed with Cars and Cars2 themed items and it matches great.
summary: Coolest bed there is?  My son thinks so.....

I admit I waited a couple of weeks before removing this toy from it's bubble wrap and checking it out. So for awhile there I didn't realize it had an off switch. Which is apparently left in the 'on' position by default. Which makes me wonder if the postal workers who came into contact with this package had any auditory surprises.

Because sometimes when my neighbors slammed a door or a cupboard, my apartment would shake enough to jostle the toy and cause the bubble wrap to set off the teapot. Now, the teapot would be sitting on it's side, because that's how I set the package down. Then the teapot would sing or brew tea. And then immediately you'd hear a sound like the tea was being poured out... and out... and out... and then the teapot would lament that it was all out of tea. The first time this happened I just gave it this look and muttered at it under my breath. After I jumped three feet in the air, of course.

But the next time this happened, I brewed the tea by pressing the little heart. Which led to what felt like a time loop, as the teapot would pour out her tea faster than I could brew it.

And then there was that moment when we realized the teapot would chat with you when you lifted the lid. And -- surprise! Inside the teapot it a mirror. Which was kind of cute.

But it isn't all that educational. There is no real feedback from the teapot on if you are getting the answers correct. So, much like ordinary, non-talking toys, you and your child will get from this toy what you make of it. Which isn't a bad thing, after all.

First I wanted to share why the product gets 4 stars instead of 5. This is because it comes with so many pieces, but doesn't come with a way to store those pieces when not in use. This can be fixed with a gallon size zip up plastic bag, though.

I think this product is fantastic for helping kids understand that the weather can impact our day, and especially how we dress. It also helps with vocabulary for the days of the week and months of the year.

Perhaps the way that using this product has impacted us in the most unexpected way, though, is with learning to dress oneself. After dressing the monkey appropriately, my daughter will then go to her room and dress herself appropriately. It has made a big difference in how seasonally appropriate her outfit choices are!

Overall, great product! I did receive a complimentary kit for review, and am sharing my honest thoughts.
summary: Great way to teach weather, calendar, and even self-care

reviewText:
Another durable and detailed PLAYMOBIL kit!  So many zoo exhibits are included here: lions pen, penguin play area, concessions booth, entrance, balloon vendor and several animals and people to populate the entire zoo.  I wish there were a bit more continuity between the exhibits, but it's not a huge deal; just looks a bit sparse when laid out on the floor or table.  This kit is especially nice for multiple children to play with.  My kids both had areas of the zoo they would 'manage' and visit each other.  They fought over the human baby a little, but there are also animal babies and even tiny 'toy' animals to sell in the zoo, so they compromised by splitting them up.  This kit includes seven humans, which was really surprising. Wish they were more racially diverse though.  Assembly is pretty easy, though the little pegs that hold the fencing for the lion cage are a bit of a bear to insert.  I stuck them to the fence first then used the fence to press down the pegs and that was much easier on my fingers.

Given the detail, relative ease of assembly and build quality, this is a great PLAYMOBIL set for children of all ages (4 and up...)
summary: This kit is especially nice for multiple children to play with

Megatron Rocks! The premium version is alot more realistic and detailed than the original version with all the great features. The advanced automorph technology triggers electronic lights and sounds around the chest,eyes,and shoulder decor. I know most people prefer the Megatron of G1 in his handgun form,but this is an awesome figure that if you are a Megatron fan you must consider. Megatron comes with a Rocket Claw that becomes a Chain Whip on one arm which he uses to do some damage in his escape from section 7 in the movie. Another cool feature is that his arms combine to form a Fusion Cannon just like he did in the movie as well. The detail from top to bottom is some of the best around and really gives Megatron a more realistic look. His vehicle mode is a cybertron jet mode which is very sweet looking once you get him to his vehicle mode. The poseability for battles with Optimus or other autobots is simply the best. The transformation level is super conversion or advanced meaning if you have plenty of experience with transformers there is still a challenging difficulty. If you are a parent buying for a child of 5-6 or younger you will have to help some in the process. Megatron is on awesome transformer,but he can be very challenging for a younger age group. The trickiest part of the transformation is getting Megatron's legs positioned just right in vechicle mode. This part can take some practice and patience. The durability of Megatron is outstanding to say the least. He can take whatever comes his way and then some. Bottom line Megatron Premium Leader is a high quality,well-made,10 out of 10 figure that all transformer fans should enjoy. I highly recommend Megatron Premium Leader to all transformer fans and collectors alike. Transformers Rule!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

reviewText: Super cute! My son loves it.

All I can say is that I am amazed at how sturdy this thing is.  Yes, it does require a little muscle to put together, but it stays together! We bought this castle used when my son was 18mo.  Now he is 13...  That's over 10 years!

The castle has been used outside in rough Colorado weather, set up inside our house and has even traveled to several houses.  We have taken a mallet to it to disassemble and move it, and the pieces are still perfectly intact.  We let our neice use it for a few years and then got it back for our 2yo daughter. Now it is in our basement and our 13yo and his friends will still climb all over it and jump off the walls.  My 2yo daughter climbs all over it and loves the slide.

This thing is tough and safe!  It does not tilt.  It's very sturdy.  There is a space around the door to prevent little fingers from getting smashed. A small child can climb into the tower and not fall out because of how the tower is designed, they can easily climb up the slide since they can use the walls to grab onto, and also hide in the "dungeon" (part under the slide and under the tower).  There is also a secret passage they can fit in through.  The bigger kids (and adults) have a blast hiding in it, climbing on it and jumping off it too.

I'm not sure about other playhouses, but I think this one is well worth the money, especially since after all these years with plenty of use and abuse.  The color faded on the Little Tikes symbol and the fireplace decal is scratched up a bit, but other than that, it looks almost new.

Even our cats love climbing and hiding in the castle!
summary: After a decade and plenty of abuse the thing is still like new!

I bought this Mr. Potato Head as a Christmas gift for my 2-year-old son, and it's been a big hit. It was only $5 when I bought it, and I can't think of many toys that are such a great deal. As with any Potato Head, the parts can be a little difficult to get in and out of the holes, but that also means the parts will stay put when they're placed. (It also means it's a toy that will "grow" with my child -- he'll be capable of playing with it in different ways as he ages.)

My set came with all the pieces shown -- hat, eyes, ears, nose, mustache, teeth, feet/pants, hands, tongue, and glasses. Unlike what some other reviewers have experienced, our set is plenty sturdy and I can't imagine any of the pieces breaking.

And fun fact: In the beginning, Mr. Potato Head toys used REAL potatoes (or other fruits or veggies) as the base. In 1964 Hasbro introduced the plastic potato.
summary: A Favorite Toy in Our House

reviewText: Great deal my boy loves it

This is a simple mostly wooden Thomas the Train set, the track assembly helps young children with eye hand coordination but might need help getting the right pieces in the right place so it all connects making a figure 8. The train goes in two groves to keep it on the track and is hand pushed along the track. As the train goes by the steam ship streamer pop out of the smoke stack. Most of the parts are wood but the train and car it pulls are made of wood and plastic, the rear cargo is a wood block. The train cars connect using magnets, don't worry the magnets are well mounted to each car and not a swallow risk. This is made for children 3 and up, none of the parts are small enough to swallow but you don't want younger ones cheewing on the track tabs or painted wooden parts so beware of this if you have infants. Price seems a bit high but quality is excellent so it comes at a price from Fisher-Price. To extend this set you can add track and or other train cars and Engines too!
summary: A simple well made child's first train set with Thomas the train Engine included.

reviewText: I received the Fisher-Price Little People City Skyway this week and it took awhile to put together, I have never seen so many screws for a children's toy before! My husband tried putting it together without looking at the instructions (typical) and then had to take it back apart and rebuild using the instructions. I thought it was strange that the light on the side doesn't do anything and the "crane" you can put the car in on the side does not move. My daughter is almost 2 and this was taller than she was so she had a hard time reaching the top of the tower slide. She enjoyed pulling the crane off and watching me put the cars down the slide from the top. She would put them down the slide from the middle. Two days later I am still trying to get her interested in this toy but she looks at it for maybe 5 minutes and then moves on to something else. Maybe she will like it more at some point but so far I am having more fun playing with it then she is. * I tried this product for free, thanks to Fisher-Price*
summary: Nice Idea for a toy but wasn't for my child.

My family LOVES Uno Roboto.  At first, I was unsure that the gimmick of the Robot would prove to add anything to the game.  Boy, was I delighted to find out how wrong I was.  My son, 10, and his cousins, 8 & 12) all ask to play this game whenever we ask what game we should all play.  The robot holds the Uno cards (slightly smaller than the regular deck).  Play goes on as usual with each player taking a turn.  Every once in a while, the robot throws out a command that changes up the game.  Sometimes you pick up a few cards, other times you might discard a few.  At the beginning of the game, each player records their name so the Robot knows who is playing each turn.  The boys all love it when the robot commands them to change the nickname of a fellow player.  They get to record a new name for another player.  With three boys, you can imagine some of the lovely names they bestow upon one another.  The robot also lets them create new rules for the game.  Sometimes they make a player pick up extra cards, other times, they make the players run laps around the yard.  The educational part of the game comes in counting the cards at the end of each hand.  It also teaches basic rules of gameplay and helps teach the little ones how to win and lose with dignity (okay, some of the adults can use those lessons, too).  Uno has been around forever and can be enjoyed by all ages.  This Robot is not a necessity, but it has brought a lot of amusement to our home.  I am surprising even myself by giving this game such a high recommendation.  A great birthday party gift for hard to buy for kids, too.
summary: This little gadget makes a great game even greater!

My 2 year old loves the M&K farm animal beads that are geared for kids more her age. She is nuts about my jewelry and loves butterflies so when I saw these beads in a craft store, I grabbed them up. The package says 4 and up (obviously these are a choking hazard), but she's a pretty laid back kid who doesn't usually put things in her mouth. I supervised her carefully and only bring them out when we can sit together. However, I would watch her with these--even if she was older. Beads like thse can be really easy to spill even for an adult.

That said, it's not a problem. I didn't get these to keep her "busy" (we have other toys or give her chores for that ;) ). Stringing these beads is great for her hand/eye coordination, creativity, and self-esteem (she is proudly wearing her first beautiful necklace). She likes to count the beads and point out the colors to us (so at her age, this is strengthening her number and color skills). She can put the little ones on very easily, but needs a little help from me or my husband with the butterflies (they are a little tricky) but I'm sure she'll master them all in no time. :)

But the best part of all (for me) is watching her while she strings the beads together. It has been a wonderful bonding experience for us that brought back happy childhood memories of when my sister and I making jewelry at bead stores in Ithaca. I very much recommend this for butterfly-loving preschoolers or toddlers, and we will probably get other sets like it. :)

Im a mom that really pushes my kids to play with blocks, Legos, art stuff, mind games and the such. I like getting their mind going and keeping them away from electronics. This is such a great set for us. I have a 1 1/2 year old son, a 3 year old nephew who we spend a lot of time with and an older daughter. This set is perfect for the younger ones and my daughter actually enjoys jumping in and helping them build things.

My son loves that he can pull them apart and then they get pulled back together when they are held close. He can push one brick around and more will get picked up. He still has a hard time playing with Legos, so these magnets are perfect for him. I obviously watch him like a hawk when hes playing with these, although he hasn't put anything in his mouth in months. Its such a great safety feature that the magnets are actually in the piece, not glued on. Being an ER nurse I look for safer toys like this.

These don't have as many options as Legos, but are easier and faster to play with. We can build and disassemble something in a few minutes. The magnet is pretty strong, Im posting a picture of some stacked together and held upside down. I've had magnet toys that are so weak they fall apart easily. These are the perfect magnetic strength for my son to not get frustrated. They are strong enough to old quite a few together. I have no issues with this set at all. I was sent this to test and review. That has no bearing on the rating or review I am giving it, I have no problem being honest with my reviews. This is just honestly a great product for our family!
summary: This is great for the younger ones! I love how easy it is to build and take things apart.

My wife and sons got this for my birthday earlier this year and I just finished putting it together this past week.  I definitely had a good time putting it together.  There are no real assembly instructions, so it's a bit of a challenge, but once you figure out the numbering system on the panel diagrams it's pretty straight forward.  It just takes some time to find the proper pieces amongst all the other pieces.  The back of the box has small diagrams of the 13 plywood sheets with each of the parts labeled with alphanumeric codes, like D6, F21, etc. and once you find the pieces you need for the section you are working on it's as simple as Tab A goes into Slot A. The instructions on the back of the box say:

1. First of all, check the part numbers shown in the drawings with the numbers on the diagram.  Mark each part with its corresponding number.

2. Push the pre-cut pieces out of the wood boards carefully and touch up the rough edges with the enclosed sandpaper.

3. Put all the parts together in order and refer to the photograph on the cover to get a general idea of where each part goes.

4. Glue is required at some joints.  Glue not included.

5. Before or after assembly, you may wish to stain, varnish or paint in your own choice of color or design.

That's it for instructions.  They are repeated in what looks like Spanish, German, and French, too.  Unfortunately the instructions and model itself aren't completely accurate.  It starts with the name of the model itself.  It's labeled as St. Petersburg Church, but in actuality this is a model of St. Basil's Cathedral.  Also, glue is included, although you'll probably need a lot more than what they give you, unless you want a very rickety structure.  I also found that some of the parts were mis-numbered on the diagrams.  It wasn't hard to figure out what the correct numbers should have been, but it happened about 4 times.  A few of the pieces were even cut incorrectly.  For the most part everything fit together, but there were a few spots where the tabs or slots were off by as much as 1/8 of an inch.  You'll definitely want an xacto knife to help trim some of the pieces.  You'll also definitely need an xacto knife to remove some of the pieces from the panels.  Yes, the pieces are all pre-cut, but not all of them are cut completely through the thickness of the plywood sheets.  Even with the xacto knife there were still a few instances of pieces splintering a bit, but a little glue or putting the splintered sides to the inside where they aren't visible took care of most of the issues.

Overall, I had a lot of fun putting this together in the evenings over the past week, and I suppose that's what matters most.  Your finished model will be pretty impressive at first glance, but under scrutiny it'll be obvious that pieces weren't machined all that well.  So for Fun Factor this gets 5 stars.  For quality it gets 2 stars.  Overall I give it 4 stars because I enjoyed it and would be happy to get another kit like it.
summary: Fun to build, could be better though.

reviewText: I ordered this for my grandson in California since I was in Alaska quite a while back. His mother held on to it until I got down to see him so I could help him put it together (that was not my plan). He and I laid down on the living room floor and got into it.  You need an AA battery and a good little phillips (cross head) screw driver. We also fetched a tweezer to hold some of the little screws in place before screwing them in. He is 10 and very capable but it was definitely a two person job for first timers.  Also one had to be somewhat instinctive with the directions.  Once you get it together the thing works and is fun.  In the end I was happy my daughter waited for me to come down as the project provided some good bonding time, some solvable challenges (tough but not too tough) and and some laughter as well.
summary: Grandpa and Grandson bonding and problem solving quality time

Gearing up to host an "armory" for games this summer - and making sure we can load up the Hail-Fire properly - I bought five of these to accompany my original three from my old Stampede. It was interesting to see differences in performance. For the TL;DR:

Even among each other alone, the elite mags performed inconsistently in terms of feed strength. While most pushed very strongly - making it difficult to even load 18 sometimes - they were inconsistent in feeding. This seems to be because they give a much, MUCH more snug fit than others of the type, be it standard or even the elite Firefly mag. For this reason, dart tips dragged on the walls constantly, hindering the feeds. To fix this, you have to tap or shake the mags to get them feeding again. Kind of annoying.

For this reason, I still favor the old Stampede-accompanying standards. Sure, they "feed slower," but mine are consistent. No darts drag and I never feel like I have to "reset" them. They're a much looser fit on the darts which can cause a bit of wobble and shifting while handling, but it's nothing to worry about.

In the end, "they're mags." They're a mass-produced product that're going to have some inconsistencies. It's just part of the territory. Still, they do their job and the price is right. Go for it.
summary: Not all mags are created equal.

We have other Little People sets, but this one is a favorite.  I like toys that appeal to a wide age range, and this one sure does.  Our one year old twins love the camper just as much as the four year old.  What makes it unique is its versatility.  The littlest hands like to push the durable vehicle around, but fold-out camper details turn it into fun imaginative play for older kids.  As with all FP Little People Sets, everything is well constructed, safe and easy to operate.  The strong hinges that open up the camper and door can withstand lots of toddler abuse, and the spare back tire conveniently closes the whole thing back up.  I especially like the indentations in the camper and boat seats that keep little people securely in placetoo often toys forget little details like that, but its an important feature for our little guys.  It may take a while, but they make sure everyones tucked into their seats before pretend play begins, and I like that it helps with finger dexterity.

For its price, this is a wonderful toylots of detail, easy storage and just enough electronic features to enhance imaginative play.
summary: Fun To Drive, Fun To Pretend Camp

I've spent over $400 on high-end RC helicopters in the past, all of which broke after some time wasting all my money (not even from crashes but the boards went bad for no reason). I got this as a gift for my birthday and I have to say from my first flight this thing, it flies amazing, if not better than all of the expensive e-flite helicopters I have bought in the past! If you are looking for RC fliers whether you are young old, beginner or advanced, look no further than this.
Out of the box, this thing is fantastic. It looks sleek and I instantly noticed versus my past experiences in this hobby, the blades are very sturdy and should be friendly to newcomer pilots. After about a half hour, the battery was charged, and I did my first test flight. I was simply amazed how well this thing flew, the stability and control are excellent, and even the transmitter feels like a high-quality RC transmitter. Modifying the trim was a breeze and I really enjoyed my first flight!

I simply love it, it is a great gift and I can't wait to flight it again! My only minor dislike, the transmitter light on the quadcopter itself is kind of bright, but no big deal and I'm sure it's helpful when flying it far away in the backyard. I have some first buyers tips if you are reading this. First of all, the screw in the transmitter is ridiculously tiny, I recommend picking up a set of tiny electronics screwdrivers so you can get it off right without warping the tiny screw. I bought a set in Home Depot for about $5 bucks, they were "Husky" brand precision screwdrivers.
Secondly, if this is your first RC helicopter/quadcopter ever that and you've never flown, I have some tips to avoid you getting sad/upset with a busted toy. Yes, this thing is very sturdy, but I would still be cautious with it! Keep it away from pets and flight it somewhere very roomy for your first flight until you get the basics down. Find somewhere with open space or even go to a gym after hours when you can learn the basics. Outdoors is OK but only if there is no breeze, if you are inexperienced in flight, the slightest breeze will take this thing off to China! First, learn getting up and off the ground with your left stick (elevator). Then learn movement with the right stick (pitch/roll) to fly forward/back/left/right. Movement on the right stick should be very delicate at first. I would not attempt flips or anything till you are very comfortable.

Also, if you get nervous and/or are about to crash, simply thrust the elevator down (left stick) all the way and let the blades stop spinning! Let it fall, you will do the least damage in crashing when you DON'T let the blades crash into stuff while they are spinning. Letting the motors run and crashing it what breaks blades/motors/gears. Don't let that happen.
I love this and I will update my review if anything bad comes of this product, but I love the Dromida Ominus! Very cool toy for adults, this was a gift fro my 25th birthday and I love it!
summary: From an experienced RC flier, this thing is amazing!

reviewText:
This was a gift to the kids last year for the holidays. A year later, I can write an informed review.

This is a *really cool* product in concept and potential that is somewhat less cool in actual execution. First, the great:

- Tons of room for creativity
- Really gives kids a project to get involved in
- Really gives kids a sense of confidence
- Lots of fun when things are rolling well

Now, the less great, which have to do with the technology interface:

-(1)- We have been generally unable to make the tactile part of this workthe actual putting little blocks into the grid. The problem is that the app relies on a phone or tablet's camera to capture images of the board as you lay out the graphicsand it invariably gets all of the colors wrong. Greens turn into blues, blues turn into purples, and so on.

We have tried it on two different Android tablets (a Samsung Galaxy Tab and a Kindle Fire) and on an iPad Air. Basically, the image processing in the app just isn't sophisticated enough to deal with average lighting conditions and average tablets. Perhaps if you have a spectacularly high-end, recent tablet or really neutral, well-controlled lighting your experience will be different, but for us it's three tablets, in sunlight, ambient room light, lamp light, and multiple different rooms and... bupkis.

Happily, you can just lay out the graphics in the app yourself without having to use the camera and the blocks. But that removes a bunch of fun from the start.

-(2)- The app (especially onboarding) is buggy. You know how some apps and services sort of "get lost" as you sign up if one little thing doesn't go quite right, and then you're trapped in a kind of never-neverland where it's asking you to do things without giving you a way to do them, or removing options that should be there based on your not having completed steps that it never gave you the chance to complete and so on? Yeah, we had that experience each time we tried another tablet. It just doesn't go smoothly.

There's a lot of "hmm, try tapping that" and "but it says we have to..." and "I don't see that option..." and so on.

-(3)- The app is not intuitive and not well-documented. The kids eventually got there between exploring and reading and so on, but it took a while. If your kids are not absolutely dedicated to figuring this out and making it work, I can see how it might turn into a "can't figure it out now, maybe I'll come back to it someday" kind of toy.

-(4)- The app is *heavy* in its resource usage. It stresses our tabletsall that we triedright to the limit, resulting in lags, some UI weirdness, and a lot of used space. I get that this is probably just par for the course given the features (especially the social gaming features) they're offering, but that also takes some of the fun out of it. Sometimes the kids just get frustrated with the lags and so on and move on to something else.

All in all, given the price and the ultimate potential over time, and the eye-opening concept that "I can build a game!" I'd say that it's worth the buy for the right kids. They should be:

- Bright
- Motivated
- Patient
- Creative
- Self-directed

But it's sort of a shame that this isn't a "knock it absolutely out of the park" product because it feels like one of those products that had the absolute potential to be, but was maybe just let down a little bit by trying to do too much and/or getting just a little bit sloppy about releasing without being ready.

Three stars and a "recommend with significant caveats."
summary: Could have been spectacular. Instead, merely "pretty cool."

reviewText: I originally wrote this review for Flash Point Fire Rescue 2nd Edition. So, please excuse me if you read it twice (but, I thought I'd include it here as well since I didn't know where folks would start). We like co-op games when we find a good one. There are not a lot of great options out there, but when we find one we like it has a regular space in our gaming rotation. Just to give you a few points of reference, Pandemic is one of our favorite games and we play it regularly. Others like Forbidden Island, Forbidden Desert, Star Trek Expeditions, and the Lord of the Rings all have something interesting to offer, but just did not do it for us so we don't play them anymore (though we do sometimes break out Forbidden Desert when we want to introduce someone new to co-op games). I'd place Flash Point somewhere between these other games; not as good as Pandemic, but much better than the rest. So, I'm giving it 3 stars, which on Amazon means "It's ok." While there are some things to like about the game (innovative mechanic, strong theme, multiple difficulty levels, and lots of expansions), there were a couple of key issues that put it in the "it's ok" range for us. (1) Our main feeling about the game was that there were too few real decisions to make. Most of the time the only good choice was obvious... you either move toward a victim or fire, carry a victim out, or put a fire out. Only occasionally do you have to make a tough decision about doing one or the other, discuss strategy, or plan for the future (see next point). Pandemic (which should be a familiar point of reference for many people reading this) offers a lot of real choices options/choices, and often requires a lot more planning and discussion (i.e., where and when should we meet, build, treat, cure, play special cards? What's the best way to get around the board - drive, direct flight, charter flight, shuttle flight? Should I save this card to cure disease, give it to someone else, or use it to fly somewhere? Etc.). There are definitely some decisions to make and opportunity for discussion in Flash Point, but nowhere near as much or as often. (2) The reason you cannot plan as much for the future is that both fire placement and victim placement is completely random throughout the game... You NEVER know where they are going to pop up. Pandemic (to use a familiar point of reference again) also contains a random component, but in a way that allows you to plan ahead in a meaningful way (i.e., after the first outbreak you know something about where the disease may pop up again so you can plan accordingly). Together, these two issues took a little out of the game for us. I know lots of people love this game and I mean no disrespect to anyone by saying any of this. I liked the idea enough to give it a try, and I liked the game enough to also try a couple of the expansions. For example, I've since purchased the Veteran and Rescue Dog expansion and 2nd Story Expansion which do seem to help somewhat with the first issue I raised above. And, I'm sure we will still break out this game from time to time as it does have some nice things going for it and we by no means felt that it was bad. But, all things considered it really felt just ok to us.
summary: A decent but not great co-op game (better with the expansions)

Friend brought this to board game night. This is a betting game that's simple to learn and requires a bit of luck and strategy to win. We had 6 people, which I think is a good number to play with. The product is frequently in/out of stock for some reason depending on who has it available (our friend said it was out of print and he had to order from UK so happy it was on amazon!). You basically get three coasters per player -- they are obviously popped out of a larger sheet. The pieces are really simple so you COULD make your own set, but the art is gorgeous. As noted, there is no protective film or coating on the coasters so they will get wear and tear, but we felt that was part of the charm. As folks noted, folks COULD mark the pieces so they can cheat...but I guess if those are the types of folks you play with, that's something else. I definitely prefer this art to the original game's art. I think this would be a good team building game since it lets you see how different players bet, how focused they are at winning points, aggressive/passive, etc.
summary: Simple betting game, but lots of fun for 6 people!

Really a well-made game. It isn't technical at all. My busy four year old didn't have much patience for it, but I can imagine other four year olds enjoying it. My six and seven year old children absolutely love it. It is quick, teaches them to ask good questions, and the scene is very well done.

For those of you who do not know the game at all, it is a guessing game. A player picks up a small square with an image on it (an image taken from the gameboard you are playing on). The other players try to guess what image the small square has on it by asking questions that can be answered with a yes or a no. Whoever guesses correctly gets to take the square image... if no one guesses, then the player who holds onto the square gets to keep it.
summary: A fun and well-constructed game for 4-8 year olds

Got these for my son for Christmas. These figures aren't really kid's toys. It seems like they had to choose between being realistic and being a good toy and they went with realism. I would never buy these for my kids again.

For example the hands are very small and don't hold the light sabers well. Normal toys have hands and accessories that are made to fit together and the accessory almost snap in place. Not so much with these. The light sabers are so thin that when they fall out of the characters hands (which they easily do) it was hard to see them. These will absolutely get lost within a few days. When I look at the picture on Amazon, I'm guessing it was altered to make the light sabers look heftier.

The figures themselves are about the size of old school action figures, but aren't made with plastic that feels sturdy like a well made toy.  If you collect them to put on a book case or something they are probably great, not so much though if you are a kid who wants to play with them.
summary: Pass if you are buying them as actual toys

Considering the price, it is a pretty good dress.  It's very pretty, and the sequins go all the way around the dress, unlike some other similar Barbie-friendly dresses I saw reviewed on Amazon.

As other reviewers have mentioned, the bustline is made for the traditional Barbie, not the smaller bustline of the modern Barbie.  This means that although the dress stays up okay, Barbie will have several "wardrobe malfunctions" during a play session.  However, it's also the easiest dress the kids can put on their Barbies (and if you've ever had to dress and undress a Barbie fifty times in one play session, you know what I mean!)

Also, it's true that the fabric is fragile.  After a week of very heavy play between my kids, both dresses need some minor repairs.  But considering these are made with much finer fabrics than you'd see on a Barbie doll, and given the reviews, I expected it.  The sewing is not bad for the price (definitely not great), and the dress looks FAR nicer than the cheesy fabrics that some of the genuine Barbie clothes are made with.  All in all, I would buy one of these dresses again.  If you understand the limitations, you may be happy with this dress for the price.  But if you don't want to do an occasional repair, and want them to last a year or more, then you should skip it.
summary: Very nice for the price, but you will need to occasionally repair it to maintain it.

reviewText:
This Hip-Hop goose is great fun. We had fun terrorizing our puppies with it. Guess they don't appreciate hip-hop music.

The goose came very well packaged. It was NOT going to move around in its box and get damaged.  It is sturdy and seems very well made.

You will need a Phillips head screwdriver to open the battery compartment and the toy takes three AA batteries (not included).

There is a toggle switch on the bottom. You can turn on to low volume music and higher volume music. It does not run on SILENT.

As it moves, it raps a hip-hop song. If picked up by the neck, it asks to be put down so it can dance. Its beak moves when it talks and sings. Its arms move, its legs move and its head bobs around. There are also flashing lights. As it walks on the floor, if it runs into something, it turns itself around and goes in a different direction. I am using it on hardwood floors. I'm not sure how it would do on carpet.

It is cute , bright and cheerful - perfect for a toddler to chase around and dance with.

Made in China.

NOTE:  I received this product in exchange for my honest review.
summary: Great for children crawling and learning to walk

This is a great puzzle, perfect for learning letters of the alphabet and their corresponding order. The images on the pieces are really attractive and appealing to look at, and putting the puzzle together is great fun... as long as you plan in advance a place to lay out all 10 feet of it, or accept that you may have to split the puzzle in two halfway through (my daughter gets very upset by the latter solution).

We bought this for my daughter when she turned two, and although she liked it and could put it together with a lot of help from us, she was nearly three before she could appreciate the order of the letters and really understand the correlation between that and completing the puzzle. If I had it to do over, I may well have waited until she was three to give this puzzle to her.

I'm really pleased with how durable this puzzle has been. It is made of really thick heavy-duty cardboard, the pictures are glossy and have held up well to a little abuse. The pieces are smooth, particularly at the edges, and appear to be high-quality.

The only huge drawback I can see with this puzzle is, as another reviewer noted, the letter x has a fox, emphasis on the last letter, which is just... wrong. I mean, why not have a xerus (squirrel) or a xiphias (swordfish) as some of our ABC books have? Really, had they put any thought into this detail, they could have conjured at least a dozen possibilities. Were they just being lazy?

Otherwise, I think this is a great addition to a puzzle collection, and is a fun and engaging tool for children just becoming acquainted with recognizing and ordering the alphabet correctly.
summary: Great Puzzle; Warning: Takes up Lots of Floor Space

This kit comes with everything you will need for a water color experience (very handy option instead of piecing together each item individually at craft store or online).  There is a paintbrush (with bristles at each end), colors for mixing (with instructions), a palette, and 3 paper canvases (stronger than regular paper).

The super cool thing for us was the wax outline that insures that the painting is close to perfect.  This was crucial for my middle school perfectionist on the autism spectrum.  Without the helpful outline he would have gotten frustrated that his painting didn't come out "right."

It doesn't teach you how to paint, it's more of a guide for these specific pictures.  We loved the beach landscapes and found the painting itself to be relaxing and challenging (some of the sections are quite small).

This is a nice gift for a pre-teen child or budding artist (teen to adult).  My grandfather would actually enjoy this as well for an afternoon activity.  I plan to purchase other sets by Ravensburger.

reviewText:
We got this game as a fun way for our son (just 1.5) to start learning his letters. Obviously, he's still too young to play the game like you're supposed to - it's designed for ages 3-6. But he enjoys the "pop" action and playing with the letters.

The actual game is very simple. The child is simply supposed to put all the letters in place before the timer runs out and the letters all "pop" out of place. The timer has three difficulty settings - the easiest setting gives lots of time. The child can play with all the letters, or all the vowels, or a group of letters of the same color. For older players, a card inserts onto the game board with spots for forming words. The instructions say to just make the words on a card that is also included. It might be fun to challenge the child to make up his or her own words from a set of letters, though! We look forward to trying that aspect of the game once our son is old enough.

Unfortunately, the letters are pretty small. This makes it difficult for our young child to put them in place (after we show him where they go). I also think it might not be as easy for him to learn their shapes when they are so small. Maybe this helps increase the challenge for an older child, though.

Our biggest complaint, though, is that the game doesn't come with any way to store all the small pieces! Lose one letter, and it's not a complete game anymore. I put them in a ziploc bag in the box, but I wish there were a storage tray or even a bag included.
summary: Fun game, but small pieces and no place to store them

reviewText: I'm giving this 5 stars for creativity. The object of the game is to rescue the princess before night fall.  The board is set up with, I think, 6 obstacles placed in a pile of decending order in the bottom middle of the castle.  Cards are placed upside down in the 4 corners inside the board: the forest, mountains, field, village. The player's pieces all start in random corners of the board. You roll the dice and move your piece clockwise around the board. If you land on the moon, you place a night piece  over the castle. If you land on a rainbow, that's a wild card and you can choose to flip any upside down card on the board. If you land on a setting space, (village, for example), you can only flip a card in that location. Once you flip the card, you see if you can imagine a way to use that item to eliminate the topmost obstacle. If you can imagine a way, you tell everyone how you are going to do it by making up a story (maybe if you get a candle, you can set the door on fire, for example). Anyway, it's fun to play with young kids and use creative thinking to try to win the game.
summary: it's fun to play with young kids and use creative thinking ...

I stumbled upon the Kre-O USS Vengeance in a Toys R Us store and picked it up as soon as I saw it.  This is the newest Star Trek set to come out in this line, and I have all of the other ones.  Each one has been a fun build, and for the most part I haven't had any issues with any of the sets.  I had a feeling that the USS Vengeance would be released at some point in time, as it was a fairly important part of the new "Star Trek Into Darkness" film.  I didn't expect it to come out in August, though.  I fully expected it to be a release sometime in the winter to go with Holiday shopping.

Full disclosure about my brick building set history here...

I've built hundreds and hundreds of LEGO kits in my life, and currently have several very nice display cases in my home full of LEGO products. While the Kre-O products may not have quite the same fit and finish as most of the LEGO products, I feel that they are a very nice alternative...and they are an alternative that will be having some licenses that LEGO will apparently never have. Star Trek being one of those licenses...so, if you want a brick building kit of some Star Trek vehicles, then Kre-O is your only option. However, I don't really think that's a bad thing. While maybe not quite as refined as the LEGO kits, I have built all of the Star Trek kits and a couple of the Battleship kits and haven't had any real issues with the builds, and the products seem durable enough. Now, mind you, I'm not a kid and I don't have any children, so I can't say that they'll survive being slammed into a wall by a 5 year old, but they aren't just falling apart like some people seem to suggest in the various reviews here on Amazon and other sites.

The USS Vengeance build went very smoothly.  There were no points in time during the build that I needed to take anything apart or go back numerous steps.  One thing that Kre-O sets require is that you pay attention to the instructions.  There are many times when a single piece is placed somewhere in a build step that doesn't really make a ton of sense.  What I mean is that you will be building a part on a certain side of the model, and then in that same step a single part will be thrown onto the model nowhere near the other pieces you are putting on in that step.  From time to time this can cause a builder to go back a step or two in order to try to figure out why things aren't fitting the way that they seem like they should.

The Vengeance has one tricky part, and it's necessary for the build the way the ship is designed.  The USS Vengeance in the movie had a strange saucer design that had the bridge separate from the rest of the saucer, and as such there is a hole in the saucer.  This is present in the Kre-O set, and in order for the whole thing to stay together there is a clear piece that must be put in the front of the saucer that moves back to the cockpit area in order to support the entire thing.  This piece is clearly (no pun intended) in the instructions, but it took me a moment to figure out what exactly it was going to do.

Other than that, the build was very straightforward without any hiccups.  The pieces on the Kre-O sets continue to seem like they are getting better.  I know some of the very early sets I had from this brand had parts that didn't want to stick together very well.  I only ran into that in one step in this build, and it was remedied by putting the pieces together completely.  Basically, it was a flat single peg wide piece trying to hold three larger pieces together, and that piece alone wasn't holding.  However, once I got the bottom of the subassembly that I was building in place, the top piece that wasn't holding before had no problems staying in place.

Like all of the other Kre-O Star Trek sets, this one has LEDs.  If you have the USS Enterprise, the LEDs on this set are exactly the same as on that one.  They are very bright and really add a cool factor to these sets.

One thing I wanted to note as it was mentioned in another review is the size of this ship.  It is very slightly smaller than the Enterprise set in overall size, and it doesn't come with as many pieces.  In the movie the Vengeance was much larger than the Enterprise, however, I don't feel that things like that need to "scale" correctly in brick building sets.  An example would be the Kre-O shuttle set.  The shuttle is obviously much larger in comparison to the Kre-O Enterprise than a shuttle would be to the Enterprise in a movie or TV show.  So, although the Vengeance was larger in the movie, I see no problem with this set being slightly smaller in size than the Enterprise, as the Enterprise is clearly the "flagship" of this line of toys.  With that said, the Vengeance is not MUCH smaller than the Enterprise.  In fact, the two sets use the same main piece that holds the saucer and nacelles.  So they are very similar in size.

Overall, this was a fun build.  It didn't take me a very long time, but it was a fun build.  The finished model looks great, and is a perfect piece to put on the opposite side of the shelf that your Kre-O USS Enterprise is on.
summary: Another Fun Kre-O Star Trek Set...

This is a good game.  My family did enjoy playing it.  It definitely is intended for the recommended age range though.  I have some that are a little younger and it was much more difficult for them to play.  But, it might not necessarily be for kids older than the range either.  So in that respect, it has a narrow age focus.  This is because it is very skill based.  So for those younger, it is a little hard and for older it might seem to easy.  This is also a downfall because if you have an age gap among players, it will put those younger players at a disadvantage.

It is a fun race against the clock (or timer) to see if you can actually build the things on the cards and how many.  So there's an excitement there.  And then, to also see if you can knock down your opponents towers.  My kids enjoyed these aspects.  And who doesn't like flinging something from a catapult.  And I do like that it helps with visual skills (colors, shapes, placement of objects).  Also some motor skills with the stacking.  So it's fun, just beware of the ages of players.
summary: Fun game.  Some excitement.  Narrow age focus.

The only thing that had to be resewn was after 2 months, the thread that held the bow on came loose but it was an easy fix. My daughter was so proud of herself for making such a nice nightgown for her doll and doing it all by herself that it was a huge lift to her self esteem and now she doesn't want me to buy the expensive American girl clothes, she wants more sewing patterns so she can make them herself! At long last, Funko releases Doctor Who figures!  I've been waiting for quite some time for these little guys to come out, and they do not disappoint.  And here we have the current and already one of my favorite versions of the Doctor.  The Twelfth Doctor played by Peter Capaldi is not young and hip like David Tennant and Matt Smith, but grizzled and grumpy like the first Doctor play by the late William Hartnell.  And even with only one season under his belt, Capaldi has shown the current series is still in good hands.

 The Twelfth Doctor has his grey-haired head, black shoes, dark navy jacket with red lining, white undershirt with a tiny little navy blue for his vest, and a ring on his marriage finger done to detail.  His dark blue/black pants from the show is a dark grey for the figure, I guess to offset the colors a bit.  And last, but not least his trademark sonic screwdriver in his right hand with the little 4-pronged claw on the end with the green at the tip.

It's about time Doctor Who was added to the growing POP! collection and it is looking good.
summary: Funko Twelfth Doctor Looks Great (He Still Doesn't Do Hugs Though...)

reviewText: Kids love it, provides hours of entertainment. Held up well  to their rough play

When my first child entered school, I put together a little pencil box for her to use when she did her homework.  Pencils, erasers, glue, and scissors.  I let her help me choose the scissors and she like these because they were the same ones she had in Kindergarten.

These scissors have supported many school projects and I've even bought a second pair for my other child.  These are great little scissors, they cut well, and they really fit the kids' hands.  When they grab my kitchen scissors for a quick cut, I always think there's going to be a scissors mishap, but I've always felt comfortable with them using these Crayola scissors.

Sandboxes have got to be *the* place that toddlers and preschoolers gravitate to. My son was most certainly a sandbox fan and I was hard pressed to get him out of it. The only problem with sand is that it sticks to anything and everything it comes in contact with, especially if its wet. Sand is certainly one of those things I don't care to continually sweep up or vacuum, but if you have a little one theres a solution for that. One of the best things about the Sands Alive kits is the fact that young children can play and be creative sans the mess. The kits can be used time and time again whether they are using molds to create mini structures or, in the case of the glow sand, drawing on. I do love the little cars in this one because thats yet another thing my son adored ... cars. Cars and truck go together quite nicely. The track is very bright and vibrant, but Id recommend getting it laminated if you want it to last. Its quite durable, but Im sure this one will get plenty of play time. The proprietary sand formula doesnt stick to anything, yet is firm enough to be molded easily if you have molds (other kits come with them). Now theres a nice new twist to the Sands Alive kits ... they actually have glowing sand! Its great fun to play with. The sand catches a glow when the either the UV glasses or the UV pen is pointed at it. I can put my hand in the sand and actually create a visible print. Loads of creative fun thats just a bit different every time its played with. INCLUDES: Sands Alive! Glow Sand (1 pound) UV Pen UV Glasses Three Car Body Molds Three Car Chassis Four Street Signs 16 x 16 Color Play Mat Decals (for the signs and cars) There are no heavy directions, no assembly, just a lot of fun. The only thing youll need to do is open the bag of Sands Alive!, fluff it up and let it sit for a few hours before use. I would have liked to see more sand, but you can purchase extra Sands Alive! Glow 4 Pounds Bulk Glow in the Dark Sand to go with this or any Sands Alive! Glow kit. These Sands Alive! kits are great fun and will last for a long time, long enough to be handed down to other children. SANDS ALIVE! Darice, SA23005W, 2 Pound, Sands Alive Play Sand Play Visions Sands Alive! Sweet Shoppe Play Visions Sands Alive! 3-D Dino Kingdom Play Visions Sands Alive! Merrilee Mermaid and Friends Play Visions Sands Alive!, Large Play Visions Sands Alive! Deluxe Starter Set includes 4 molds and tray EXCLUSIVE KIT, LIMITED EDITION!! Play Visions Sands Alive! Sunken Castle Discovery Play Visions Sands Alive! 5-Pound Bulk Bag No Mess Sand Sample provided for review.
summary: Sands Alive! is a perfect playtime kit for hours and hours of creative fun ... without the mess of regular sand

This is a wonderfully weird and unique plush toy perfect for any child, ocean lover, or plush collector!
I purchased this as a gift and was so pleasantly surprised by how cool this toy was! It was a gorgeous deep color and was made so incredibly well. I truly don't have a bad thing to say about it. My family has been rotating this toy around our various homes for several years now and it still looks like new, so needless to say it holds up to tons of play and use and abuse!

The eyes are securely attached which is surprising because so many plush things have their poor little eyes come loose after a few washings and some wear. But not this guy! And his tentacles are amazingly constructed and attached extremely securely.
When my kids were younger this was a favorite toy and those little tentacles got chewed and mouthed and twisted and tied up but you would never know it by how great it still looks!

The coolest thing about this toy though is that it actually has a little beak in the mouth area just like a real squid! SO COOL!
Everyone loves this, adults and children alike and I would recommend this for any age group. The tentacles are not long enough to be a potential strangling hazard, and the body is soft and fluffy enough to make for a great cuddle toy.

reviewText:
We have had this toy for several years and two children; it was one of the first toys we bought.  The blocks are easy for a baby to pick up, and are easy to wash.  The yellow lid doesn't stay firmly attached, but it isn't supposed to.  A young learner will take off the lid, put in the blocks, dump it, and repeat.  As they grow the may put the lid back on and try to stuff the box to the gills with other thing.  The one day, when they grow the right brains for it overnight, they will try to smash the blocks into every hole until one works.  The circle and triangle and square will be the first the learn because they go in easiest. Once they learn colors, you can direct them to fetch a color or shape or say it wrong to see if the notice.  The circles tend to roll far!  So if you can't find them, look under furniture that are farther than you think.

This has gotten a lot of use in our house.  Sometimes the five year old brings them out to stack and crash her cars into, to the delight of her younger brother who then likes to play Godzilla after she builds a tower with them.
summary: Easy to clean, Easy for a young baby to use and explore

reviewText:
My husband and I are both avid shutterbugs, and my almost 3 year old son really wanted a camera to take his own photos. We had a few gift cards that we had not used, so we invested in this camera. He was very excited to get it and uses it often, he especially likes to take it on Photo Safaris with us. It is also a hit in the neighborhood among all the kids who take photos like crazy with it.

Pros: Seems quite durable. Buttons are easy to use for him, while the batteries and sd card (optional) are easy to keep out of his reach. Photos download easily and cable is included in the kit. The optional SD card (I got a cheapie 512meg) adds storage for over 1000 extra pictures.

Cons: Does go through batteries quickly- but we use rechargables anyway for most things. Photo quality is TERRIBLE- and I just don't mean terrible because we are photographers ourselves, I mean TERRIBLE in general. The photos are most frequently blurry and dark- even with flash or bright sunlight. Also, I don't think they would even print well at 4x6 but we have not tried.  We will have to upgrade him to a cheap digital point and shoot once he is able to treat this camera nicely. (I will upload a few sample shots to customer photos.) Another con is the discard photo button is right there on the back- great for them to erase the photo they just took without realizing it. It also makes a rather annoying noise when any button is pushed- which encourages the button pushing to go on and on and on.

OVerall, the camera performs as expected, just wish the photo quality was better, but again, this is a camera for my preschooler so I should not expect too many megapixels I guess.
summary: Durable Camera, Easy to Use, Photo Quality Below Par...

My 2-year-old doesn't yet understand princesses, but she loves to play with this castle nonetheless.  There are enough simple moving parts to entertain her, including a dance floor where the two dolls can "dance" to music and a button to push that sounds like twittering birds.  But I'm also really happy that there aren't too many "bells and whistles" here.  The simple layout and furniture forces children to involve their imaginations in their play, and that's a really good thing, I think.  My daughter loves to sit the dolls at their table for meals and put them to sleep in their bed.  She actually likes this castle a lot more than the fancy (and very pricey) doll house we got her recently.

Great little tablet, AMAZING battery life. My kids are a little young (almost 4 and almost 2) so they don't really play many of the included games yet and I wonder if by the time they are old enough they'd want a "grown up" tablet but we'll see. The screen isn't anything amazing but does the job- I've seen worse. The ability to add my own apps is why I bought this- there are some games like Sago Mini games I wanted to add. The fact that this only has the Amazon store and not Google play sucks more than I realized. Also, sometimes it chokes and won't install something from Amazon for days. I'll pull up the app and it'll still say "install pending". Happening right now with my ABC mouse app. So we have that on our Nabi- which is a far better tablet but the battery life is so bad I don't think I'd get another! Once I tried putting on about 4 Amazon apps on and it was pending for hours- then they all installed out of nowhere! I can't figure out what causes that so while you can add apps you are greatly limited and it's frustrating. If the app options for outside apps was better I'd give it 5 stars. The only reason this isn't getting 3 stars is the battery life is amazing. I can leave it unplugged overnight and come back to almost the same charge as I left it. Meanwhile our Nabi Dream would be dead or on its last legs even if it was 100% when we went to bed. I'd consider buying it again but can't say 100%. The kids actually broke our first one by pulling on the cable while charging and broke the port so we got a replacement through the warranty. I was seriously considering buying a replacement at that time but got the Nabii and now we have 2 tablets. Which our boys fight over since they each have different advantages and apps so there's always something to fight over! Esp if they want to watch YouTube- not goo player for that on the LeapFrog. Still, if you don't care about side apps this is a nice device.
summary: Great battery life, nice tab, needs Google Play

I bought this as a power upgrade for my Traxxas Rustler XL5.  It worked great.  Gave the car more power and it lasts much longer than the 7-cell stock battery.

This also comes with several adapters for different connectors and they work great,  they're very short and the resulting plug with the adapter isn't much longer than a standard plug.  I put some super glue on it to attach the adapter permanently but I'm not sure that was really necessary.

I've charged it many times since I got it (I'm guessing around 40 times) and it still holds about the same amount of charge it did when I got it.  One thing I'll say is it gets a little hotter than I'd like when charging, so I've reduced the charging current to 2A and set the peak detection to a very low threshold which made it better, but it still gets pretty hot. Much hotter than the stock Traxxas battery.

reviewText: This is a riot! A dog that poops. The purpose you say? Besides being funny, it may teach a child how to be a responsible dog owner. Dogs make messes, right? It also helps them feel like they have a real dog. They can name it, feed it and care for it. Simply insert the pellets in the mouth and feed, walk the dog and let it poop. It comes with a durable plastic leash and tag. The eyes are wide and expressive, as well as attached very well. The fluff on this toy is so soft and realistic. However, it is very easy for smaller children or even real pets to swallow the small plastic pieces as far as the food. Definitely not for a child under four or five years old (unless supervised and you put it away). It also requires two AAA batteries, (again, choking hazards and even poisonous if bitten into), so please heed that warning if you purchase this adorable little toy. Other than that, I think it's a great idea. The pup is also vocal. I don't like that it is made in China, but since you won't allow the child/dog to chew on any part of it that's not a huge hazard. Check on their website at www.furrealfriends.com for other specific questions.

My daughter (age 11)has this and the Nerf Rebelle Agent Bow Blaster with purple arrows. She loves the bow blaster set, but this Rapid Red Blaster did not work properly at first. My daughter had to tape something down inside of the compartment that had been blocking the bullets from releasing. It works fine now and she enjoys playing with it, but I think it's a repair we'll have to do again. She likes the fact that she can load multiple bullets at once instead of reloading each time. The range is pretty far. As with the Bow Blaster, the secret message function is kind of silly; the messages can easily be read with the naked eye, and are trite. An improvement would be to be able to write actual messages and insert them, or other small objects, in a capsule inside the bullet. In any case, after exactly one reading, the messages and decoder become pointless.

It's a little unclear what age group these toys are targeted for. The pink and purple theme tends to appeal to the younger Disney Princess crowd, but I can't help thinking it looks like a blow drier and there's nothing "rebel" about it, whereas older girls such as those pictured on the product pages would probably prefer more sophisticated and realistic colors and designs. The Nerf Rebelle Rapid Red Blaster is a lot of fun, but different color options and a better secret message system would, I think, appeal more to the preteen age group this set seems to be aimed at.

I have to admit that buying this toy, the Step2 Extreme Coaster, was my wife's idea.  I had doubted that our kids would play with it long enough to justify it's price.  But, three years later, they still enjoy it and ride it often.  Below are my pro's and con's to this coaster:

Pro's:
- It's extremely sturdy, and even after multiple times assembling and disassembling the ramp, it still fits together tightly
- It's simple to use ... your child just pushes the cart up the "stairs", climbs into the cart, and pushes off
- It's safe for little children.  My (nearly) three year old even uses it by himself (though under my watchful eye) as does his older siblings, and after three years of useage, and we've never had any accidents with their pushing the car up the steps, climing in, or falling out of the cart (although you've got to be on your toes to keep anyone from wandering in front of the toy as the cart comes down the ramp)
- Since your child has to push the cart up an incline, they get a bit of exercise

Con:
- None, really, although the ramp itself is pretty heavy (which is also why it's so sturdy, so it's not really a "con")

For the first year we owned it, we kept it indoors when not in use, but that got to be a lot of work to partially disassemble and reassemble, so for the past two years, we've just left it outside.  It's weathered well and we don't feel the need to bring it back indoors.  Depending on the type of surface the cart rides on (grass, sidewalk, etc.) and the slant of your yard, the cart will go from about 20 feet to a heck-of-a-long way before coming to a stop.

Overall, this is a great toy that the kids don't seem to get tired of.  And during playdates or birthday parties, all of the other kids really enjoy riding it, too.  Five stars.
summary: The kids still enjoy this even three years after buying

From what I understand these action figures were originally meant to be sold separately at the time of the release of Batman Begins, but I guess Mattel decided to concentrate on their less detailed sculpts instead. Now with the movie a success, the Movie Masters line was released, ensuring a much more steady stream of money from fans who prefer a more detailed action figure.

Unfortunately these figures are half an inch smaller than the Movie Masters line but still they look very good and I am glad that they are released.

The first is James Gordon, I have to admit its nice that he's brought in especially after the character was more involved in the movie than the previous movies. The figure comes with an accessory of a toy gun that manages to fit in his hand. The second is Bruce Wayne dressed in the prototype Batman suit, compete with a rubber balaclava style mask like he wore in the scene when he first meets Gordon in his office. The toys are very good. Could have been bigger, but still a very nice set.

We have several Lego Star Wars sets and were thrilled there was now a Star Trek Klingon D7 Battle Cruiser to make. My 12 year old son loves both series. Overall the design was very nice, the finished product looks quite good.

However there were a few issues. Some pieces fit too tightly, requiring way too much force to assemble, while other pieces were too loose
and fell out.

The instructions were great, with multi colors helping to figure out the orientation of pieces, but one set of pieces were reversed from a paint perspective, and would not align properly which goes back to the quality control question with fitting.

Overall we thought it was a nice representation of the battle cruiser but there were several quality control issues that we just haven't seen with Lego products. I would give it a 3.5
summary: cool that there are now buildable Star Trek ships, but the quality control could be improved

Really disappointed in this Jack in the Box.  I had originally thought about purchasing a "real" Jack in the box that played "Pop Goes the Weasel". But, after seeing this & the song it played, I knew I had to buy this unique "Jack in the box" as a Christmas gift for my young grandson.  Even at the age of 1, he absolutely loves anything that plays music.  But, the music (if you can call it that)  doesn't even sound like Puff the Magic Dragon - not even remotely close.  In fact, the "music" is barely discernible at all.  At times, it may play 1 note, every once in awhile.  There are such long lag times, when no music at all plays.

There are also times, when the lid won't shut, after the dragon pops up.  But that is easy to fix.  For those having the same problem, just turn the handle backwards, until you see the little red latch on top, pop back up.  After doing that, you can push the dragon back in the box.  The tin box is really thin & not even close to what I thought I was purchasing.  I would think for the price of this jack in the box, not only would it be made with sturdier metal, but I the music should at least play, so it at least sounds like the song.

The only redeeming quality of this jack in the box, is when the dragon pops up.  My grandson is young enough that he likes that.  It doesn't hold his interest, like some of his other musical toys do.  More than likely, with how cheaply is is made, it will probably find it's way into the trash bin before too long.

reviewText: My son was an absolute heaven when receiving this. This is such a great replica of a Thunderbird chat. He has played with it for hours already!

My son is a bit of a camera snob. He's 'broken' at least one of my older point and shoot cameras, so he's on lock-down with kid cameras for a while. We previously used the VTech - Kidizoom Digital Camera, which is about comparable to the Playskool one in terms of functionality (though our Vtech has a flash and the Playskool does not), picture quality (both are pretty 'awful' even with bright daylight) and durability (though I think the Vtech edges this one out). I think the controls on the Playskool are much easier for a preschooler to operate (my son is 3.5yo), and the shutter 'speed' is quicker with this camera. But the best thing you get for the $10-15 extra bucks you'll pay for the Playschool camera is the projector capability. My son loves it. The image is presented on a weird grid-like backdrop, but it's clear that it's the picture he took. He likes that immediate large-scale gratification. I'm not bothered by the lack of a USB cable since most of us have millions floating around. Overall, cute, not disappointing, but not amazing either. I wish someone would make a kids camera that had slightly better picture quality. Kids do manage to take some interesting photos from time to time, but the resolution on these cameras leaves MUCH to be desired.
summary: Cute Camera Concept, but not as exciting as the 'real' thing

My friends and I are huge Twilight fans so we could not wait to play this game.  I previously purchased the New Moon boardgame which was dissapointing because the questions were really easy and the game was not all that fun - so we were really hoping that Scene It would fullfil our desire for a fun Twilight Game - which it totally did!  The game plays like a typical Scene It game with both DVD questions and questions on the card.  There are two dice included - one with numebers and one with pictures of the different challeges.  It can also be played on half of a board - or you can expand the board for more players and depending on the amount of time that you have.  The only complaint that I have about the game is the board itself - it is flimsy and did not unfold into a flat position so the game pieces would not stand up.
My friends and I really enjoyed this game - the questions were challenging which made it really entertaining.  It contained a ton of clips from all 3 movies.  There are also bonus features on the DVD such as Party Play - which is just continuous questions with no stopping.  We had so much fun with this game and can't wait to have our next Twilight Night.  Definately pick this up if you are a fan of the series.  Please note that the questions are all based on the movies and not the books.
summary: A must have for any Twilight Fan!

My review philosophy:
As a longtime customer of Amazon, I depend on others' honest reviews. I do my best to provide that same courtesy to others.
I purchase lots of items through Amazon, some I get for free, some I get at a discounted rate, and some I pay full price. I will always disclose if I receive an item for free or a discounted rate. I do a lot of reviews so here is a break down on how I determine my star rating of a product:
5 stars  I love it! It is awesome and I highly recommend everyone to purchase this product!
4 stars  I like it, but there are some flaws. Don't we all have flaws? I would purchase again.
3 stars - It was okay, but I would probably not buy it again unless there are no other options.
2 stars  There may be worse products out there, but you can definitely find better choices.
1 star  I dislike the product, I wish I had not purchased it and recommend others to not purchase.

reviewText: Has your little one been begging you for an iPod? Or stealing yours to play games? The LeapPad Leapster Explorer Globetrotter Pack is a fun and educational toy for a wide range of ages. My 2-year old grandson is the primary user but his 9-year old sister likes it, too. Even if he's not playing a game, the unit is set up so he can't delete or destroy anything if he's unsupervised. This toy definitely holds his interest for long periods of time. Finally a toy that challenges him to learn more, rather than master and move on to the next toy. This toy will grow with him. Both downloadable content and traditional cartridge games are available for purchase. For children under 6, the ability to download games to the Leapster and not have cartridges, which can be easily lost, is a real plus. It has a touchscreen that works with either fingers or the attached stylus, and a D-pad and buttons. This makes it very accessible to kids with all different use styles. It is as exciting as a DS, and more educational. My grandson calls it his iPod and takes it everywhere.

My video doesn't show me playing with the motorcycle, just what you get, which is a substantial and fun toy. It comes with a large rechargeable battery pack, regular batteries for the controller and a 4gb mini-SD card. Kids should get a lot of fun out of reliving daytime play experiences by watching the videos. It's pretty much a dirt bike in miniature and I think if you have some vacant dirt available for kids to make a track on this is the sort of toy that could keep a boy and his friends occupied all summer. It's fast, a little challenging to learn to drive and it will do tricks kind of on its own depending on what's underneath the back wheel. It has only one throttle speed, fast. The steering is also hard left and hard right so its likely to handle best on flat pavement or on a home-made dirt track.
summary: Fast, fun and likely to keep kids very occupied.
