reviewText:
This toy is out there all over the place in different forms and this is nothing new. It requires batteries and fires disks about the size of a large washer. It doesn't fire them at very high speed but they do travel a long ways. The nice thing about that is that as long as the kids aren't aiming the thing two feet from somebody's head, they won't hurt anybody. Even then, as long as the disk doesn't hit an eye that close it probably won't hurt either... much.

It has a sturdy design to it and has a strap that wraps around the wrist so that the shooter can walk around with it like a souped-up Spiderman. This would be a really cool item if it weren't for a couple of things that are really annoying. First of all, the blaster comes with 10 disks, but only 5 of them actually fit into the load area. So, after you fire 5 shots... you have to unstrap yourself in order to reload. Given the size of this toy, I think they could have brainstormed a little more to figure out how to fit all 10 disks.

Secondly.... no, that was it.  That one thing is really annoying.  This is a fun toy that could have been made better with a little more thought and it really isn't anything new.  It's just a rehashed concept toy with a new design to fit a new movie and make new money off of a done and done again idea.
summary: AMAZING SPIDERMAN 2 MOTORIZED SPIDER FORCE We.....  err.... DISK BLASTER

Fantastic set to build and display, unfortunately it is a bit fragile. The way a few parts are designed to fit together is somewhat curious. The nose cone, the hood, the rear cover and body panel, and the dashboard piece all come to mind. The hood could easily be remedied by adding a few more studded pieces to hold it in place better. Along with that, the nose cone has fallen off several times just by picking it up to admire it. The rear body panel is held on with just two hooks to make it angle appropriately, but given some time I think I could find a better way to achieve the same look. The rear cover includes part of the roll bar that is not attached at all to the main bar, and simply rests in place at an angle. The entire dashboard/windscreen is held on by one axle piece, and wiggles easily. It should also come with skinnier tires, to match the real Seven and not have them stick out beyond the fenders.
The Caterham Seven certainly is a tricky car to turn into Lego, so for the most part the original Ideas builder and the Lego designer did a good job. I still think it could be refined to make a more solid, finalized product. It was very fun to build, cool to see how they solved the problem that is the Seven's unique body shape.
summary: Fantastic to build and display, too fragile to play

reviewText: Saving for a stocking stuffer.  I know my grandson will be wild when he gets it.

This is an excellent product that is a lot of fun for many ages.  Thanks to this unit we have an active club going strong.  Forgive the long review, but this unit deserves it in my mind.

Pros
Fun -  It is a blast, especially in groups.  This really is for adults as well as kids, and if you get a group of people together to do this, you will have a blast. There are many videos of people playing with this and previous generations on Youtube. Search 'Phoenix LTX', 'Tagfest', 'Lazer Tag Team Ops', and you'll probably find a lot.

Range - These taggers (guns) have a range of about 350-400 feet, maybe further (maybe a bit less in bright sun).

Features - These taggers have several features to enhance the playability.  a) 10 or 25 tags - you can set a switch to set your 'life' at 10 or 25 tags.  This can help balance some scenarios where differences in numbers or age/experience might make things unfair.  b) Indoor/outdoor mode - this helps reduce the sensitivity of the receivers - reduces splash damage you get while playing inside.  The IR signal can reflect off walls and make it pretty easy  to take hits, even around corners and off your clothing.  c) Accessory connectors for more options (see below) d) Realistic reload - you drop a fake 'clip' out of the bottom of the grip, much like an ammo clip.  e) realistic recoil - there is a hammer that lights up and pops out a little with each shot, and also a vibration with each shot/hit that add to the experience.

Accessories - There is already a shotgun attachment developed, as well as a green dot site.  These slide on to connectors on the tagger to give additional capabilities.  There are also rumors of more weapon attachments in the pipeline.  There was also a video game accessory to let you play 1 player vs. the computer on a TV, but it was pretty useless, and you probably won't see that any more.  If you play with the older LTTO style taggers, you can actually join games hosted by the older taggers.

Exercise -  Depending on your gameplay style, you can get as much exercise out of it as you want.  The range on these guns is hundreds of feet (a bit less in full sunlight), so you can easily get winded running around inside the playable area.

Eductional - I know - it's a shooter game... but it teaches basic strategy, tactics, and teamwork, and even the younger kids are starting to pick up some of these concepts.

Durability/Battery life (cost of ownership) - The taggers (guns) are very rugged - if you compare the cost of the system with a commercial lazer tag rental facility- you will make your money back in a couple of sessions of playing, and these taggers last a long time.  We are still using all of the taggers we bought over the year, though some of them are developing glitches.  Battery life is also very good - even with rechargeables (which seem to be a little less effective, but much cheaper in the long run), the batteries will last several sessions of playing.

Online Communities - Very active online community (there's several newsgroups including an active one on Yahoo, search for 'Lazer Tag Team Ops'). The user community and the available technical information on the web opens the door for tech-minded to tear them down and 'mod' them to give them additional features. You may have to solder some stuff, clip some wires, or similar, but some of this is pretty cool.  Even me, the solder-novice - has gotten into this a little bit with a few minor mods.

Interaction with others - You can play team-based games of 2 teams.  The largest game we had was 36 players at once and it was a bit chaotic, but fun.

Cons -

Can't change the brightness of the LEDs - these are EXTREMELY bright while playing at night, and not only can this effect your aiming, but it gives away your position.  We find 2 layers of scotch tape colored with black sharpie work well to dim it down a bit.

Joining hosted games is painful - Mostly a complaint about interacting with older taggers - joining LTTO hosted games is clunky at best.

Lack of Attachments - This is not a failing in the unit, but this particular packaging. This set is a re-offering of the original LTX, which came out last year, but this set has been rebranded under the Nerf brand.  Unlike last year's model, this set is sold without the green dot sight and 'shot blast' attachment (at a lower price, granted). I believe it's their intention to sell the attachments separately, but they are not on shelves yet. In this economy, that may not happen if the interest in the line doesn't improve. That would be a complete shame, since this is one of the coolest 'toys' I've ever played with.
summary: A TON of fun, especially in larger groups

reviewText: I was so excited to order this for us!  I was more excited than my kids to play with this classic.  Got it set up and it ran great!  I was prepared to come here and write about how the penguins went all the way up with no issues, went down the track smoothly and over and over.  It did all that - for about 5 minutes.  Then the stairs started knocking/locking occasionally, then almost constantly.  It's an obnoxious clanking noise.  I had high hopes and it was perfect at first, but as it warmed up was a no go.  Returning it.  I wish a US company still made these a bit more quality.  The ones we had growing up ran like champs for years.

reviewText: We are a Waldorf family and have a deep appreciation for good quality, natural wood toys. We have a small mix of beautiful pieces by Grimm's Spiel and Holz and some handmade items from Etsy. I have hoped for a block set like this for some time. If any of you have shopped for a little rainbow stacker of any size, you already know that they are going to cost you almost as much as this entire set. Here is what you will receive: 10.5 inch Solid Wood Storage Box 4.5 inch wide rainbow stacker. (Smallest blue piece is 1.5 inches wide) 6.25 inch triangle nesting set 4.25 inch nesting square set 4.25 inch nesting rectangle set Two 9.4 inch long yellow building planks (my son was very excited about having these!) A mix of classic building blocks, rectangles and triangles ranging from 1.5 to 4.5 inches The blocks have a very nice matte, light lacquer finish on them. I know some people are purists and prefer only beeswax finished wood toys but I did not find these blocks to be unpleasant to the sense of touch or smell at all. There is no chemical smell to them whatsoever. When the blocks arrived, my son was eagerly waiting to play with them and play he did! He set up the blocks in various configurations on our white shelf so I could take some example images then settled himself onto the living room rug to enjoy his new toy. He built and built and built. Later he retreated to his room and set the blocks up again, working with them in various ways. (In the background are his other waldorf toys. The curvy blocks are from Grimm's.) I snapped a few pictures of some of his various creations. What is amazing to me is how soothing natural toys are. The whole time my son was playing the house was quiet and all I heard was the gentle tap of wood blocks being stacked one on another. It was as calming to my ears as it was to his! I very highly recommend investing in these blocks. They are delightfully colorful, interesting and unique. Your son, daughter or grandchild will be charmed by their simple appeal and endless ways they can be played with! I was incredibly fortunate to be able to purchase this stunning block set at a slight discount to try out before writing a review. We love Waldorf toys and this block set now has a permanent spot on our very selective toy shelf! I hope that by sharing my pictures and experiences that you are able to make the best buying decision for your family!
summary: Delightfully Charming Waldorf Block Set  4.5 inch Rainbow Stacker Included

My 2 year old loves to write letters, so I know it would be a hit for him. some of the reviews say because of the way the floaters are laid out, its hard for their kid to swim because they either have to be flat on their back or on their belly, but our 21 month old can actually wade in the pool on her own vertically. it actually helps her learn to float and determine where her center of balance is in order to stay afloat. also, our girl is only 23 pounds and this was one of the few suits that she can actually wear since most require kids to be 30 pounds

As an Educational Insights Insider, we received this toy for review in our State-of-the-Art Toy Testing Facility here at Rock Father HQ (our house).

I've bought so much Playfoam over the years... in fact, it was the first product I ever purchased from an Educational Insights booth at the Chicago Toy & Game Fair some years back.

The kids love it, and my wife and I love it as well - a way to tap into much of the same creative play and artistic appeal as modeling clay or various "dough" products, but without the mess.

This particular set is fun, but the "undersea" vibes are really just a cool way to package it. Every parent that's ever purchased Playfoam knows that it NEVER stays separated by colors, and eventually it's all mixed together in a big ball... but that's totally fine. No matter what the shape, the kids love forming it into new creations over and over again.

reviewText: I had great expectations from all the position 4 and 5 star reviews of this game. I have a few board based fantasy games like Descent and Heroscape, both great games giving hours of replayability, and obviously high quality of design and materials. This one disappoints. All of the pieces give the word MINIATURE and new definition. The pieces are so small they are in the description realm of RIDICULOUS. FFS is obviously saving dollars in name of sacrificing quality and quantity. Some of the pieces, like the plastic gold coins and the pyramind cones are literally 1/4" in height and diameter.  The handful of plastic molded characters are at most about 1 inch high as well. The spell and casting cards are all so small they would be small for a 5 year old's hand. The board is quite large, about 3 foot by 2 made of cardboard. Not much here folks, especially for the cost of the game. This is a 12 dollar game at a 50 dollar price.

reviewText:
I have recently purchased this brainteaser puzzle from Amazon and really like it very much.
It is the latest brainteaser from SmartGames. I would like to say that this is my favorite
brainteaser puzzle. While other SmartGames portable brainteaser puzzles were
pentominoes-based and were sufficiently challenging, I believe this is the most challenging
because in addition to the basic pieces in the layout, you need to solve the remainder of the
puzzle by surrounding the main pieces with the appropriate chain links which is the hardest
part. I am currently on the Starter level and boy was it challenging!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! However
it is a motivator to try the more difficult and challenging puzzles!!!! If you want additional
puzzle challenges beyond the traditional pentominoes challenges of Lonpos games, this would be
the one. Definitely purchase this brainteaser!!!

I bought this toy at our local store because the price was seven bucks and I thought it was a good buy.  Boy, am I disappointed with this toy!
THis toy is adorable, looks good, and it is recommended for 6 months and up.  Our son is 7 1/2 months and is in the perfect age for this and loves to play with this toy.  He loves to play with the rings and put them in his mouth since this age they are teething.

A couple problems occur though and all parents should pay attention here.  Infants at this age put everything in their mouths, not surprisingly, our son put these rings and big bird topper in his mouth repeatedly.  Well his lip got cuts on it after he was teething and chewing on this toy.  I took the toy away and inspected it again and now noticed that the big bird topper edges on the underside part of the orange ring are sharp!  Now I felt the sharpness before allowing our baby to play with it but did not think it would cause him harm..  So, yeah, stupid me!  Awful design flaw for sure to even say that this is for 6 months and up with this design problem is also stupid and wrong!  Anyhow, I took the big bird topper away from our baby and allowed him to play with this toy without the big bird topper.

Well today he was playing with the colored rings as I sat their right with him and he was chewing on them and rolling around and the yellow ring fell out of his hands onto his head.  That normally wouldn't be a problem with other soft plastic toys, but this is hard plastic.  This caused a red raised bump on my baby!

So, two things blatantly wrong with this toy; 1.) the orange ring with big bird's underside is sharp and will cut your baby! so be aware and 2.) if the baby drops it on them because its a hard plastic it will hurt!

Awful!  Save your money and buy something else..

Good Luck..
summary: Disappointed, it cut my sons mouth! & hurt his head!

reviewText: My kids adore Thomas and all and anything related to Thomas and friends

I love the Tag system, and I think it is a great learning tool for our Kindergarten homeschool curriculum. My daughter is a bit of a grumpy reader unless you get her on a great day, so it is important for me to have a variety of items like workbooks, books, DVDs, games, etc. for her to propel through reading.  She likes the TAG system, and it is a great tool, but until she gets through the frustration of learning to read using phonics and sounding out words, this will be a challenge.  She wants to rush, but this system is not meant for that.  It is a terrific tool, but your child will not read overnight and may not "love it" for what it is - it's not playing with Matchbox cars or a Leapster, it is reading, so be patient and use in only small doses until your child's reading really takes off.
I love to give these as gifts for kiddos 5 and under.  It's the perfect consumable gift that has some educational value as well (shapes, colors, patters, etc).

I bought this based on other reviews and others that had the older version.  I don't know what the older version was like, but one thing I really do not like about this is that it is so incredibly light, that my son has been pulling it on top of himself while trying to use it as leverage to stand up ever since he was about 7 months old.  Also, it's so light that when he's standing playing with it, it scoots across the carpet and he ends up falling.  The idea is a good one, but it seems too cheaply made.  A bit of sand weights in the legs would've taken this toy from average/needs work to pretty great.  It's a baby's toy.  It's for babies that are learning to stand.  It should be designed to not fall on top of them when they use it to stand up and should be designed to stay steady when they play with it.  It's disappointing. I had high hopes for it, but someone either got lazy or the person that designed this never had kids.

reviewText: Excellent!
Good product

Slime!

First of all, it's not all that messy of a slime. If you follow the instructions. Big if, of course.

Second, it doesn't assemble quite as perfectly as I'd like: some of the "click this into that" pieces do not click well.

Third, follow the instructions--don't approximate.

Fourth, I found the guidebook helpful with the science, but this is a springboard kit: use it to springboard into really studying the science of polymers and slimes.

Fifth, I would have loved a marketing tie-in with Ghostbusters, but that's just me.

Now, the kit comes with hardware. You need materials:

Baking soda
Borax
Corn syrup
Corn starch<--lots of it.
Food coloring
Unflavored gelatin
Glue
Lemon Juice
Liquid Starch
Ground pepper
Red cabbage
Vinegar.

Those are the ingredients for all the experiments. Have fun!

reviewText: Roar!

My brother recently bought this for my 3-year old's birthday, on my recommendation. She's technically too young, so we took to a play date with an almost 7 year old girl and 4 year old boy so the 7 year old could maybe impart some knowledge and ideas to my 3 year old. The friends  (both the 7 and 4 year old, as well as my 3-year old daughter) were instantly transfixed and obsessed. The 7 year old had never before heard of Goldibox (nor had her parents), so I gave a 1 minute demo/explanation and left them to it. I was so impressed with how much our friend's kids liked Goldiblox so much, I ordered them the same three sets we got: this one, Goldie Blox and the Parade Float,  as well as Goldie Blox and The Spinning Machine.

Today I get a text with a photo, "They've been working on this for about 90 minutes." I asked for clarification, "They're not fighting or asking to watch TV", was the response.  7 year old girl, 4 year old boy. That's awesome!

Here's hoping my 1 year old and 3 year old get there soon!

reviewText: Great quality, great price.

This is a pretty dress; the high-contrast brocade fabric is striking.  I have a problem with the gauzy overlay skirt.  It is sewn poorly.  It is only attached in the back and sits loosely and somewhat awkwardly around the waist.  I don't think that the style and color of the black shoes and clutch go very well with the outfit.

We are a table top gaming family. We have some "all around" (including video format) gamers, but we *all* sit down, at least once a week, and dedicate the evening to a table game.

This tabletop version of Escape the Room was a blast! I have to say personally, my *only* disappointment was realizing the game is a "one-off." That is, once you've played it with a group, you've solved all the puzzles and in a sense, consumed the game. (All is not lost -- the game website includes clear directions for packing the game back up to be used again by a new group of players). As it is, as soon as we finished, I was online seeking out more versions of the game!

For those not familiar - this is not a typical game that pits players against each other. Rather, players must work together to attain the game goals. In other words, everyone wins... Or no one does! It's important that your guests/players understand this before starting the game. We've spent some time working on different games with a similar approach (such as Forbidden Island), so we have been through the learning process of how to work in conjunction (and not against) each other.

We got through the game more quickly than the instructions estimated. I believe that this is because many of the tasks in the game involved puzzle solving. In our family, most of us enjoy puzzles... BUT, we all enjoy different types of puzzles. This was a *huge* advantage, because if one of us didn't recognize a puzzle type, another did... I think the estimate of two to two-and-a-half hours is very fair, especially for a group who does not  regularly play together.

If you enjoy tabletop games, solving puzzles, or even just spending time with friends in an activity-focused evening, I heartily recommend this game.

I received this game free for testing purposes. Any and ALL opinions given by me here are mine, alone.
